tropeNotes: [The Ace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAce): Heavily implied in *[Final Fantasy XII](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXII)*, and made more explicit in *[Final Fantasy Tactics A2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTacticsA2)*. In the former, it's not readily apparent since he's only of nominal importance to the plot, but side quests and NPC conversations paint him as nothing if not hypercompetent, and he has [the stats](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatisticallySpeaking) of a god. You could call him an "Ace in training"; he's got the potential, but he's still young and inexperienced.

[All-Loving Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllLovingHero): He goes out of his way to help a lot of people during the side quests, as well as letting the refugee [Aegyl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WingedHumanoid) live on his airship.

[Audience Surrogate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AudienceSurrogate): Vaan's intended to be this for the player, acting as a grounded viewpoint to the games setting and world. As a regular guy caught up in the narrative, he tries his hardest to keep up, which makes him a vessel for the player through which the world is explained to the viewer.

[Battle Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleCouple): In *Tactics A2*, he and Penelo are Sky Pirate partners and are inseparable on and off the battlefield. Doubles as a [Sword and Sorcerer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SwordAndSorcerer) pair for bonus points.

[Big Brother Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherMentor): He's unofficially the leader of the Lowtown orphans by virtue of this trope. They not only look up to him but run to him for aid with their problems. Exemplified toward Kytes and Filo in *Revenant Wings*.
[Butt-Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey): In the manga spin-off, the group regularly lampshades his [Idiot Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdiotHero) status and insults him to his face.

[Chronic Hero Syndrome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChronicHeroSyndrome): Even in the sequels where he is a [Sky Pirate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkyPirate), Vaan can never stop doing what's right. Though he still has [Sticky Fingers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StickyFingers).

[Commonality Connection](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CommonalityConnection): Vaan and Ashe have this with their extremely similar experience during the war with Archades and its because of this they can see the ghost of their lost loved ones in the Tomb of Raithwall. In the climax of the game its this bond that  (SPOILER)  allows Vaan to [save Ashe from herself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JumpingOffTheSlipperySlope) .

[Contrasting Sequel Main Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContrastingSequelMainCharacter): Tidus was a [Fish out of Water](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FishOutOfWater) while Vaan never goes too far from his Homeland, at least in this game. While Tidus is relegated to the back when meeting the locals, Vaan is [The Face](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFace) because the rest of the party are wanted men. Tidus ultimately is in his own story and Vaan is the viewpoint of several. Lastly Tidus became an [Official Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OfficialCouple) with the High Summoner while Vaan has a very low-key relationship with Penelo.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): In *Tactics A2* and *Revenant Wings*. Likewise in *XII*, too, when he get's particularly annoyed or peeved at someone or something. Although in *XII*, this is more noticeable prior to Ashe joining the party permanently. And the player is just as likely to see Vaan on the end of another Deadpan Snarker, particularly during his more naive moments.

[Decoy Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DecoyProtagonist): He's the initial viewpoint character, but once Ashe joins the party the story begins focusing on her development a lot more than his. He remains important to the plot throughout the entire game simply by virtue of being a [Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil) to Ashe and a valuable party member.

[Depending on the Artist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DependingOnTheArtist): As noted above, whether or not and to what extent Vaan being a sensibly dark-skinned desert-nation-dweller or suspiciously Nordic will depend on the art style and artist who composes his given appearance.
    - Similarly, just how athletic and hunky Vaan is depends on the artsyle, and even the very game or piece of media itself. In *XII*, FMV sequences portray Vaan at his most buff. *Revenant Wings* revamps him to appear more sterotypically "youthful kid", downplaying his physique tremendously most of the time. *Dissidia 012 Final Fantasy*, conversely, plays up his buff-ness, showing Vaan at his most cut. *Tactics A2* downplays only insofar as his loose-fitting shirt doesn't flatter his muscle tone as clearly as his vest does, but he generally back to be more atheletic in appearance than *Revenant Wings*.

[Deuteragonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Deuteragonist): After the plot shifts to Ashe, he's still the viewpoint protagonist, her [Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil), and, as her [Morality Pet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoralityPet), one of the keys to Ashe's [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment).

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Matching the several parallels to *[Star Wars](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/StarWars)*, Vaan is a blond-haired hero who came from a desert settlement and is able to use a form of magic in battle to aid him, all of which bring to mind Luke Skywalker.

[The Face](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFace): In *[Final Fantasy XII](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXII)* and *[Revenant Wings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXIIRevenantWings)*. In the former, he does almost *all* the talking to the nigh hundreds of NPCs and in the dozens of side quests.

[False Flag Operation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FalseFlagOperation): He pulls this off near the end of *XII*. He (SPOILER) uses [Balthier's](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkyPirate) [vocal modulator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGun) to pose as [Larsa](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagnificentBastard) [Solidor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheWisePrince) to convince [Marquis Ondore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WildCard) to hold back his [airship charge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeeroyJenkins) against the [Sky](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AirborneAircraftCarrier) [Fortress Bahamut](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolAirship) so they can board it and have a shot at taking out [Vayne](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) and the [Mist Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WaveMotionGun) before it [destroys Ondore's fleet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NukeEm) and [drops the rubble on Rabanastre](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColonyDrop).

[Flanderization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Flanderization): In the game proper and *Revenant Wings*, Vaan is portrayed as an [Idiot Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdiotHero) street urchin, having his moments of being gullible and cocky, as well as being [Hot-Blooded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HotBlooded) and easily angered, but never is this shown as his one defining trait, instead just a part of his character that also makes room for him to be insightful, able to reflect on his own life decisions and learn from them, as well as providing his own form of wisdom to Ashe later in the game. He does have a few occasional jokes and scenes where the party doesn't take him seriously or scoff at his naivety, but they still regard both him and Penelo as valuable allies. The manga and *Dissidia 012*, however, crank up his idiocy and naivety to the point of stereotyping, as he becomes exceedingly immature and comedic to the point where he forgets people's names often, and has *three* pre-battle dialogues in the latter game where he asks for the opponent's age, and reacts to  (SPOILER) Feral Chaos  like a child getting to a new boss in a video game.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): To Ashe, paralleling her in backstory and [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment) as a citizen of Rabanastre who lost a loved one to the Empire and desires vengeance. However, while Vaan eventually realizes how pointless revenge is and lets go of Reks' death, Ashe takes longer to get over Rasler. Atop the Pharos when he tells this lesson to Gabranth, Vaan's example inspires her to follow his lead and not use the Sun-Cryst's power.
[Friend to All Children](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendToAllChildren): He's the leader of the young orphans in Oldtown.
[Glowing Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlowingEyes): Vaan's eyes will momentarily flash [blue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OccultBlueEyes) when he uses Pyroclasm.
[He Cleans Up Nicely](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeCleansUpNicely): In *Tactics A2*, the addition of a fine white shirt to his wardrobe takes him from scruffy street thief to dashing Sky Pirate.

[Heroes Prefer Swords](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroesPreferSwords): Swords are his starting weapon and preferred weapons in sequels and in the artwork. They ([along with sabers and blades anyway](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllSwordsAreTheSame)) are the only weapons available to the Sky Pirate class in *Tactics A2*. The [Updated Re-release](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpdatedRerelease) instead gives him a dagger to start with.

[Heroic Build](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBuild): Outside of *Revenant Wings* where the artstyle portrays Vaan to look more like the stereotypical idea of a young teenager, Vaan is a very athletically toned guy. His explicit training against the rats in the Garamsythe Waterway and other like things proves to be quite the exercise regiment, which his desert-dweller's atire shows off well. This is even remarked in-universe: a Jaharan Garif notes that Vaan is surprsingly well-built for someone his young age (17, so not an unrealistic thing at that point).

[Idiot Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdiotHero): Subverted in the original game; though he's impulsive and a bit naive, Vaan is clever, resourceful, and has a fair amount of scenes where he shows a more inquisitive and insightful side. The manga, however, [makes this his defining trait](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Flanderization), cranking up his [Hot Bloodedness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HotBlooded) and making him rather arrogant and cocky, but lacking the skill and intelligence to back them up. *Dissidia 012* likewise dials up the idiocy to the point he has trouble remembering simple names.

[Infinity +1 Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InfinityPlusOneSword): In *Revenant Wings*, he gains the exclusive weapon Anastasia, the best weapon in the game once a bonus dungeon is completed to power it up.

[I See Them, Too](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ISeeThemToo): For reasons that go largely unremarked upon in-game, he can see the same spectral vision of  (SPOILER) Gerun posing as  Rasler that Ashe can throughout the game, though to him the specter takes the form of his dead brother Reks. The main point of the revelation is to reassure Ashe that she's not crazy and to hint that  (SPOILER) she might be being manipulated by it , while the deeper meaning appears to be that  (SPOILER) Gerun and the Occuria are dry-running him to be Take Two at this whole "Modern Dynast-King" bit should Ashe fail .
[Jumped at the Call](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JumpedAtTheCall): In *Revenant Wings*, he jumps on the first opportunity he saw to go on another adventure.

[Knight, Knave, and Squire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightKnaveAndSquire): The squire to Basch's knight and Balthier's knave. Vaan is callow and impressionable and he quickly picks up from both Basch and Balthier and eventually becomes a full fledged sky pirate himself.

[The Lancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLancer): Vaan plays this role to Ashe, by being her [foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil) given that he is a street urchin in contrast to the refugee princess when both have lost family to the Arcadian empire  (SPOILER)  and both are groomed to replaced the Dynast King.
[Legendary in the Sequel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegendaryInTheSequel): Already a world-famous sky pirate in *[Final Fantasy Tactics A2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTacticsA2)*

[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): Associated with the cutscene-specific song "The Dream to be a Sky Pirate", which plays as he affirms said dream to Penelo at the start of the game, with an air of inspiration and freedom. The main notes come from the song later used as the theme for the Salikawood.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak): His Quickenings are [Red Spiral](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PillarOfLight), [White Whorl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe), and [Pyroclasm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire), but they consume a substantial amount of MP to use and need skill and luck to chain together.
[Living Emotional Crutch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LivingEmotionalCrutch): He becomes one to Ashe during a scene in Jahara village.
[Lovable Rogue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LovableRogue): Vaan is a skilled thief and pickpocket but one with a strong heart and drive to do what's right.
[Magikarp Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagikarpPower): Begins at Level 1 with no LP, no magic, and barely anything else to his name. By Level 99, he's your party's MVP *bar none*.

[Master of All](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfAll): In the original release, he's got all around amazing stats, having emphasis on strength (best score along with Basch), magick (second best score), vitality (best score), and speed (second best). Stats-wise, he's easily the best character of your party. The cherry on top of the cake is that *even his attack animations* are faster — Vaan can deliver combos in under half the time than the rest of the party (save Basch and Balthier) needs to execute the same amount of blows. In the *International Zodiac Job System* release, his strength is slightly nerfed, but overall he remains a powerhouse allowing him to be flexibly placed in any job.

[Morality Pet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoralityPet): Serves a variation of this trope for Ashe. Because Vaan is a citizen of Dalmasca who's lost loved ones to the war, he's essentially going through the same beats as her, but catching on quicker: at first he lets his hatred for the Empire dominate his judgement and acts recklessly because of it, until he grows out of this mindset in favor of simply protecting his homeland.  (SPOILER) The Occuria even try to use him as they're doing to Ashe, but unlike her, his doubts vanish way faster and he refuses to take revenge for Reks' death, knowing full well it won't do him any good. Ashe follows Vaan's example and rebels against the Occuria in the process.

[Only One Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyOneName): In a game where most characters either have a last name or have taken an alias, Vaan never has his full name reveled. Courtesy of Old Dalan it's sometimes thought to be "Ratsbane", but it's a joke on how much time he spends fighting rats in the sewers and not actually his name.

[Overshadowed by Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OvershadowedByAwesome): Vaan isn't really a *bad* character, he just happens to be in a game where, as far as Western audiences are concerned, he and Penelo are not as interesting or developed as the other cast members.
[Percussive Pickpocket](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PercussivePickpocket): He does this to an Imperial soldier that he sees harassing a helpless merchant.

[Persona Non Grata](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PersonaNonGrata): He almost gets himself banned from Bhujerba due to the whole pretending-to-be-Basch-very-loudly ordeal. Thereafter, the city guides are annoyed with him and caution him to [stay away from ledges and cliffs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShameIfSomethingHappened).
[Primal Stance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrimalStance): Seems to favor these sorts of stances with his fighting style.
[Screw You, Elves!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewYouElves): His thoughts on the Occuria. Right after seeing Gerun he sees them all as conceited and manipulative.

[Sky Pirate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkyPirate): His goal is to become one, to escape the streets of Rabanastre and find freedom and fortune as an outlaw. In the sequels he's fully stepped into the role.

[The Sneaky Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSneakyGuy): He was able to infiltrate the Royal Palace of Rabanastre with a little prompting from Old Dalan and find its hidden [Treasure Room](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TreasureRoom). Balthier, a legendary sky pirate, considers it a feat on his level and he and Fran had to wait for the chaos of [La Résistance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaResistance)'s attack to achieve the same.

[Spanner in the Works](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpannerInTheWorks): His [willingness to spare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TurnTheOtherCheek) Gabranth is what prevents Ashe from completing her [Roaring Rampage of Revenge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoaringRampageOfRevenge) and becoming an [Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn) to the [Occuria](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkAssGods). It's also implied that he was going to be Occuria's plan B since he saw Reks at first where Ashe saw Rasler. He's letting go of his hatred for the Empire foiled that and led him to spare Gabranth.
[Street Urchin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StreetUrchin): At the start of *XII*, he lives on the streets of Rabanastre picking pockets and doing odd jobs for Migelo to take care of himself.

[Supporting Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupportingProtagonist): He serves as a [Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil) to Ashe, both of them wanting to see Dalmasca restored and to claim vengeance for the death of their loved ones. However, Vaan's actions only drive the story up to when Ashe joins the party; after that the game follows her entirely, and Vaan just advises her like the other characters and acts as party leader in non-combat areas. He gets over this role in *Revenant Wings*, though, whereas Ashe's is somewhat downplayed.

[Tagalong Kid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TagalongKid): He is only two years younger than Ashe and is more of [The Lancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLancer) towards her, but does not have a true connection to the main plot. This is averted in *Revenant Wings*, though, in which he really is the main character.
[Team Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeamDad): To the war orphans in Lowtown.

[There Is Another](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThereIsAnother): It is strongly implied that  (SPOILER) the Occuria are grooming him as a replacement Dynast-King if their manipulations of Ashe don't work; Vaan can see Rasler's ghost too, but to him, it looks like Reks .
[Tragic Keepsake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicKeepsake): His pendant is all Vaan has left to remember Reks by.

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): Once in *Revenant Wings*, and another, *huge* one in *Tactics A2*, where he is regarded as the greatest Sky Pirate who ever lived. Even a Criminal Syndicate has a flee-on-sight order when confronting [him](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded).

[Turn the Other Cheek](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TurnTheOtherCheek): Vaan's willingness to forsake revenge is what stops Ashe from giving into Gabranth's [Breaking Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakingSpeech) and [Jumping Off the Slippery Slope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JumpingOffTheSlipperySlope).

[Underrated and Overleveled](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnderratedAndOverleveled): Despite being just "a petty thief", Vaan's stats are *demolishing* gameplay-wise, easily surpassing Ashe, Penelo, and Fran in physical attack, Basch in magic, and [Balthier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OverratedAndUnderleveled) in *both*. All of this summed up makes him the most versatile and overall best character in the game.

[Vitriolic Best Buds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VitriolicBestBuds): With Tomaj in *Revenant Wings*. Tomaj even admits in one of his logs that he doesn't like Vaan, despite following along on their airship for the adventure. The two of them often butt heads but definitely help each other out.

[Walking Shirtless Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingShirtlessScene): The little vest he wears in *XII* doesn't leave much to the imagination of what his torso looks like. Of course, considering where he was born and raised — a desert nation — it makes perfect sense that he'd wear light clothing whenever possible. Many Dalmascan men and boys wear less. Averted in *Tactics A2*, where a now slightly older and more seasoned and established Sky Pirate Vaan wears a swashbuckler's loose-fit white shirt, leaning into said swashbuckler's aesthetic.
[Worlds Greatest Warrior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorldsGreatestWarrior): Games set after 12 paint him as being the greatest Sky Pirate in the world.

[World's Strongest Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorldsStrongestMan):  (SPOILER) If you take down the [Superboss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Superboss) of 12, as it was the most powerful creature in Ivalice, Vaan is then recognized as the new strongest creature in Ivalice .
[Battle Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleCouple): In *Tactics A2*, with Vaan of course. Doubles as a [Sword and Sorcerer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SwordAndSorcerer) pair for bonus points.

[Dance Battler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DanceBattler): Uses dances to activate her Quickenings and is a Dancer in *Revenant Wings* and *Tactics A2*, some of her attack animations are likewise dance-like.

[Flat Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlatCharacter): She had little characterization in the main game other than being Vaan's maybe [Love Interest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveInterest) and her [Odd Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OddFriendship) with Larsa. This is fixed in subsequent games, where she serves as a [Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil) to Vaan. A lot of this is due to [Executive Meddling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExecutiveMeddling). One of the two writers of the game, Daisuke Watanabe, has said that Penelo is his favorite character mainly due to a lot of content he wrote around her that ended up on the cutting room floor in development.
[Girl Next Door](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GirlNextDoor): Has this vibe to her, especially to Vaan, given that she's also a street urchin.
[Girlish Pigtails](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GirlishPigtails): For cuteness and it grows even longer in the sequel.
[The Heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeart): The sweet and loving member of the group, and the her's [Love Interest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveInterest).

[I Have Brothers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveBrothers): According to the [instructions booklet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual), Penelo's elder brothers were soldiers who tutored her in martial arts.

[The Lancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLancer): Shares the role with Llyud in *Revenant Wings* as foils and sidekicks for Vaan, who has truly stepped into [The Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHero) mold.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): "Penelo's Theme", which sounds appropriately cheerful and optimistic.
[Lethal Chef](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LethalChef): Initially her cooking was dreadful but she improves to [Team Chef](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeamChef) over the course of *Revenant Wings*.

[Like Brother and Sister](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LikeBrotherAndSister): Her relationship with Vaan was something like siblings (with Migelo as the father figure) until she is upgraded to [Victorious Childhood Friend](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VictoriousChildhoodFriend) after their [Relationship Upgrade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RelationshipUpgrade) in *Revenant Wings*.

[Little Miss Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LittleMissBadass): A short and slight sixteen-year-old girl is an accomplished warrior thanks to the tutelage of her elder brothers. As Vaan's partner in *Revenant Wings* and *Tactics A2*, she goes on to become a formidable sky pirate.
[Little Miss Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LittleMissSnarker): Gets a few good snarks on Vaan and Basch. This trait is particularly evident in her *Dissidia* cameo.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak): Her Quickenings are [Intercession](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HavingABlast), [Evanescence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicMissileStorm), and [Resplendence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LiterallyShatteredLives), but they need skill and luck to chain together. In *Revenant Wings* she gets Dance of Rapture instead, a full party heal and revival ability that she gets from defeating Ultima.

[Magic Dance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicDance): All her Quickenings and non-[White Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMagic) skills in *Revenant Wings* and *Tactics A2*. Her quickenings in particular are based on ice-dancing and figure skating maneuvers.
[Nightmare Fetishist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NightmareFetishist): In *both* *Dissidia* games, she says she thinks that the Cloud of Darkness' snake creatures is "cute."

[Odd Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OddFriendship): With Larsa. She's a Dalmascan commoner just getting by, while he's an Archadian prince being groomed to lead an entire nation. This is actually important, as their ability to become friends shows that Dalmasca and Archades's empire and people may be able to get along. They still communicate regularly through letters and remain, close friends, even after the first game has ended.
[Only One Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyOneName): As with Vaan, her family name is unknown.

[Overrated and Underleveled](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OverratedAndUnderleveled): Zigzagged in *A2*, where her and Vaan's default classes don't have very good stat gains even though they are rather helpful as guest characters and can be good in other classes, too. Her Dancer class is good as a secondary skill set. 0-cost debuffs are quite good, and the Sword Dance <sup>note </sup>  a double attack, used only if she has an edged weapon equipped  attack is very useful if she is a Spellblade or Assassin <sup>note </sup>  who wield broadswords and katanas, respectively .

[Plucky Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PluckyGirl): Defies the tradition of a long line of [Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/FinalFantasy) [Genki Girls](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenkiGirl) for a more subdued but still somewhat perky characterization.
[Only Sane Woman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlySaneWoman): She plays this role and is more level-headed and cautious to Vaan's sometimes reckless impulses.
[Replacement Goldfish](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReplacementGoldfish): When Penelo grew close with Velis in *Revenant Wings*, she remarked how much he reminded her of her deceased elder brothers.
[Satellite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SatelliteCharacter): In *XII*, she doesn't have much to do in the plot but talks to other characters. She improves in later games.
[She-Fu](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SheFu): When equipped with certain weapons, such as Poles or Unarmed, Penelo will show how acrobatic she really is.
[Sky Pirate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkyPirate): She joints Vaan in his occupation by the end of the game and sequels.

[Stripperiffic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperiffic): Modest enough in the first game (especially compared to Ashe and Fran), but *Revenant Wings* and *Tactics A2*, she's still wearing more than Ashe or Fran, but still less than originally.

[Squishy Wizard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SquishyWizard): She and Ashe are equals for the most magically powerful characters, but have the lowest strength and HP scores. Amusingly she has a very high vitality making her an ideal wielder of [axes and grenades](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GirlWithPsychoWeapon).

[Tagalong Kid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TagalongKid): Even more so than Vaan, who's motivated by his vendetta in Reks' name and being the [Audience Surrogate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AudienceSurrogate). Penelo is just there for him.
[Team Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeamMom): To the war orphans in Lowtown.
[White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage): In *Revenant Wings* and *Tactics A2*, she focuses on white magic.
[The Ace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAce): He likes to think of himself as one and he certainly lives up to his claims.

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast): His Quickening phrases.
QUOTE **Fires of War:** "I *never* miss."  
**Tides of Fate:** "Let me show you how it's done".  
**Element of Treachery:** "There's a proper way to do everything."

[Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton): While he doesn't exactly go "berserk", discussing nethicite is a good way to get his attention and make him break his usually calm and laid-back attitude. [There's a very good reason for that](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing).

[Big Brother Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherMentor): To Vaan, though not on purpose. Balthier balks at the idea when others mention the trope, and Vaan is likewise not impressed, but in practice they *do* have this dynamic.
QUOTE **Vaan:** Since when am I Balthier's apprentice?  
**Balthier:** Not the first time I've heard that joke. I'm still not laughing.

[Casual Danger Dialogue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CasualDangerDialogue): It's remarkably difficult to get Balthier to lose his cool, even when he's at a considerable disadvantage. Held at swordpoint, he comments dryly that "At least your sword is to the point," and one of his lines, when defeated in combat, is to snark calmly, "Is that your best?"
[Character Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterCatchphrase): "I play the leading man, who else?"

[Dark and Troubled Past](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkAndTroubledPast): He's actually  (SPOILER) Ffamran mied Bunansa, son of Archadia's Dr. Cid, and a former Judge. When he saw what Cid was becoming though, he abandoned his life and his name for freedom.
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Towards friends or foes alike.

[Defector from Decadence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefectorFromDecadence): When  (SPOILER) he was in service to Archadia , Balthier realized what  (SPOILER) Dr. Cid  had become and  (SPOILER) defected from the empire .

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Of [Han Solo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/StarWars); a snarky gunslinging outlaw with a [Cool Ship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolShip) and a [Non-Human Sidekick](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonHumanSidekick) that gets roped into the adventure on the promise of money and sticks around when he becomes friends with the cast.
[Fighting Your Friend](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FightingYourFriend): He and Fran are bosses in *Revenant Wings* and fight Vaan and Penelo.

[Flynning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Flynning): His attacks tend to be the least practical and have the most theatrical flourishes.  (SPOILER) It makes sense when it's revealed he's actually from [The Empire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmpire).

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): Quite a lot of it regarding his true past. Further, in the English version of the game, Balthier is the only character among the heroes who speaks with an English accent courtesy of [Gideon Emery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/GideonEmery). Dalmascans speak with American accents, thus making it an instant giveaway that he's not one of Vaan's countrymen. You know which characters *do* speak with English accents?  (SPOILER) The Archadians.

[Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation): Balthier is introduced as [The Gunslinger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGunslinger) and joins with the appropriate equipment and licenses for the role. However, he has a custom gun animation that is actually slower and longer than every other character using a gun, making him the *worst* gun wielder in the party. Conversely, despite seeming to be [The Dandy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDandy) and a [Rogue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LovableRogue), he has one of the best strength stats in the game, a close second only to a tie between Vaan and Basch, and impressive HP growths, making him well suited to frontline combat with hard-hitting weapons and heavy armor.
    - This becomes [Fridge Brilliance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FridgeBrilliance) if you take into account (SPOILER) he used to be a Judge
[Gentleman Thief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GentlemanThief): Looter and pilferer as he may be, Balthier never stops being educated and charming.

[Guest Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestFighter): In the [Updated Re-release](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpdatedRerelease) of *[Final Fantasy Tactics](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTactics)*.

[Hero Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroProtagonist): Subverted. While he insists that he's "the leading man" every other cutscene, which isn't entirely unjustified as he knows he's more important than the [Kid Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KidHero) ( (SPOILER) given his connections to [The Empire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmpire) ), but it's *Ashe* who is the true hero of the story and [who decides where the party goes and what it does.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AProtagonistShallLeadThem)

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): He makes a point of mentioning that he may be required to invoke this trope eventually, as the sort of thing that a "leading man" might be expected to do. He goes through with it during the ending when he  (SPOILER) stays behind on the collapsing Bahamut to fix its engines to fly it away from the city as it crashes (only to subvert the trope by surviving the experience) .
[Firing One-Handed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FiringOneHanded): His crossbow and rifle animations are this, which while cool slows him down a decent bit when using these weapons.
[Giant Wall of Watery Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantWallOfWateryDoom): His Tides of Fate quickening involves conjuring a massive tsunami on enemies.
[The Gunslinger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGunslinger): Ironically the special animation he has with guns makes his firing speed a fraction of a second slower then other characters.
[Improbable Piloting Skills](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobablePilotingSkills): At the helm of the *Strahl* during the  (SPOILER) Battle of Rabanastre . 'Nuff said.

[Improbable Use of a Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableUseOfAWeapon): Balthier uses all hafted weapons one-handed, notably attacking with poles in an odd manner very reminiscent of a baton twirler. His wielding spears are likewise executed from the same bizarre grip.

[Informed Attribute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAttribute): Promotional materials refer to him as a silver-tongued womanizer, but he doesn't show it much during the game. There's a couple hints he has a relationship with his partner-in-crime, a brief handkerchief scene with Penelo, and one NPC says she's smitten with him if you find her, but that's about it.

[Instant Runes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InstantRunes): All three of Balthier's quickenings have arcane geometries involved, the runes themselves being based on navigational equipment such as compasses, portolan and sea-charts as a reference to Balthier's [pirate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Pirate) status.

[Knight, Knave, and Squire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightKnaveAndSquire): The knave to Basch's knight and Vaan's squire. Balthier quickly takes a shine to Vaan and takes him under his wing, showing him the ropes of sky piracy and his aviaton know how and while Basch is quite happy to work with him, he still questions Balthier's motives before his past is revealed.

[The Lady's Favour](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLadysFavour): Played with. Balthier hands Penelo his handkerchief to assure her that he will bring Vaan back safely when they are arrested for aiding [La Résistance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaResistance). This leads to Penelo being kidnapped by Ba'Gamnan.

[Lampshade Hanging](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadeHanging): As the profile quote demonstrates, Balthier is perfectly content to perform a [Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice) because he believes that he's [The Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHero), and thus cannot die thanks to [Plot Armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlotArmor).  (SPOILER) He's proven correct when he survives the destruction of the *Bahamut* at the end of the game.

[Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam): Balthier's speech patterns tend to be flowery and boastful, though he usually avoids raising his voice too much.  (SPOILER) His dad more than picks up the slack.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak): His Quickenings are [Fires of War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire), [Tides of Fate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakingASplash), and [Element of Treachery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColonyDrop), but they need skill and luck to chain together.
[Mellow Fellow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MellowFellow): Balthier keeps a blaise attitude with nearly anything with only the issues of nethecite and  (SPOILER) his father truly getting under his skin .

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): His true name is taken from  (SPOILER) [Mid Previa](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyV) and [Mustadio Bunansa](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTactics).

[Nerves of Steel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NervesOfSteel): He is unflappable, rather secretive, and can be hilariously indifferent to nasty surprises, such as being thrown in a dungeon (where he implies he's [seen it all before](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SeenItAll)), finding out 'Amalia' is actually Princess Ashe ("Huh. Can't believe that was the princess."), or witnessing his partner flying into a [Mist-induced frenzy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnstoppableRage).
QUOTE **Ashe:** What's wrong with her? 
**Balthier:** I always knew Fran didn't like being tied up. I just never knew how much.

tropeName: Not in This for Your Revolution
tropeNotes: [Not in This for Your Revolution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotInThisForYourRevolution): In keeping with his Han Solo traits, he and Fran only stick around [on the promise of payment from Ashe, being that she's a princess pursuing ancient relics of royal heritage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyInItForTheMoney). Balthier has no interest in the rebellion or Archadia,  (SPOILER) though at the end of the game he gets invested in finding out what Dr. Cid was up to for all those years before he left .

[O.O.C. Is Serious Business](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OOCIsSeriousBusiness): It's telling something is amiss when Balthier drops all pretenses of being suave and sarcastic to start being serious about something. When "Lamont" brings up his knowledge of manufacted nethicite at the Lhusu Mines, the second he brings up the term, Balthier starts grilling the kid with questions and cornering him against a wall, *demanding* answers about who "Lamont" really is.

[Outlaw Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutlawCouple): He and Fran are a pair of Sky Pirates with huge bounties on their heads. However, it's unclear how far the romantic angle of their partnership goes.
[Pretty Boy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrettyBoy): He's *definitely* easy on the eyes.

[Poor Communication Kills](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoorCommunicationKills): In *Revenant Wings*, where it leads to a [boss battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FightingYourFriend) with [him and Fran](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualBoss) and eventually him getting slugged in the face.
[Screw This, I'm Outta Here](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewThisImOuttaHere): In his backstory, he decides  (SPOILER) to bail from Archadia for good after realizing what his father has become .

[Serious Business](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SeriousBusiness): Nethicite is the one thing he won't be snarky about in the slightest. In a slightly more humorous note, airships are serious talk for him and he treats the Strahl almost like a true friend.

[Sesquipedalian Loquaciousness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SesquipedalianLoquaciousness): He has shades of this. Lampshaded early in the game:
QUOTE **Balthier:** Ah, the prison repository of wrested relics and raiments.

QUOTE **Vaan:** So our things are in here?

QUOTE **Balthier:** That's what I said.
[Sky Pirate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkyPirate): He's one of the most infamous Sky Pirates in all Ivalice, and ends up being Vaan's role model as he becomes one himself.
[Tall, Dark, and Handsome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TallDarkAndHandsome): He's 6'0".

[That Man Is Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThatManIsDead): Though he doesn't reject it as fiercely as some, he doesn't appreciate being called by his real name when he runs into people who know his past.

[The Charmer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCharmer): Of a more subtle flavor. It helps that he has a beautifully smooth voice, but is noticeable when he and party rescue Penelo.
QUOTE **Penelo:** Here, Balthier...your handkerchief. I thought you might want it back. 
**Balthier:** I shall wear it close to my heart.

[Wrong Genre Savvy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WrongGenreSavvy): Balthier self-identifies as "the leading man" upon whom the story centers around, and tells the others that [Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice) and [Plot Armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlotArmor) can be expected to come into play with him due to this status. Despite this, it's Ashe who in practice acts as the main character, with Vaan as the [Supporting Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupportingProtagonist), and Balthier's expectations concerning his role never come to pass. When Fran lampshades this reality during the ending, Balthier is offended by the idea.
QUOTE **Fran:** I'd say you're in more of a supporting role.  
**Balthier:** Fran, please.
[Younger Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungerThanTheyLook): He's 22, but easily looks and sounds a good decade older. [No one's complaining.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TallDarkAndHandsome)

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): Fran's pretty badass in the original game, but she's on a far higher tier in the manga, having super-speed and a Blizzard-enchanted claw attack that deals an [One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill) to Firemane and freezes Ghis's sword. In the game, she finds an exit from the Nalbina Dungeons but the magick bindings are too strong for her to break; in the manga, she's perfectly able to break them, it's the Imperials outside that stop them from leaving.

[Armor-Piercing Question](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmorPiercingQuestion): She presents it to Ashe if you take a wrong turn into the [Necrohol of Nabudis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BleakLevel), asking her if she would do to Archadia what happened to Nabradia.
[Badass Driver](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassDriver): She's got a hoverbike and is an amazingly cool pilot on it.
[Beast Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeastMan): As a Viera, she's a literal bunny person.

tropeName: Break His Heart to Save Him
tropeNotes: [Break His Heart to Save Him](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakHisHeartToSaveHim): She does this to her sister, Mjrn, advising her to forget about her since she has left the Wood and should no longer exist to her. She doesn't want her sister to lose her link to the woods as she did, and considering that outside the woods a war is brewing between Rozarria and Archades, with Dalmasca and its surrounding potentially becoming the battlefield, Mjrn could become a casualty. At least Fran knows she would be safer in the woods.
[Combat Stilettos](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatStilettos): As with all Viera, she wears them to compensate for her much longer feet.
[Cool Big Sis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolBigSis): She is quite affectionate and mentorly to the young Penelo.
[Cute Monster Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CuteMonsterGirl): She has rabbit ears and claws, but otherwise has the body of a tall and shapely hume woman.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Gets a few good lines here and there.
QUOTE **Vossler:** We've secured an Atomos, come!  
**Balthier:** An Atomos? All skiff, no ship...hardly fit for a leading man.  
**Vaan:** So I can fly it?  
**Fran:** Are you mad?

[Fallen Princess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FallenPrincess): Highly implied. Her sister is the leader of Eruyt Village and it's implied that Fran would have become a Viera higher-up if she did not choose to leave the village.
[Fighting Your Friend](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FightingYourFriend): She and Balthier are bosses in *Revenant Wings*.

[Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation):
    - Viera is supposed to be very magically adept, but Fran's magical stats are mediocre at best, square middle among the six main party members. However, all other Viera stick very close to home, whereas Fran left home decades ago and is heavily implied to have lost touch with it, and thus possibly her connection to magic in the first place. - Also, despite the fact that she is supposed to be a skilled archer, her firing animation with the bow is actually slightly longer than normal, reducing her DPS and effectiveness with it compared to any other character.

[Jack of All Stats](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JackOfAllStats): In the Zodiac Age versions of the game where sheds her [Master of None](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfNone) status by gaining the highest Vitality score and her large amount of innate skills let her usefulness shine with the [Job System](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JobSystem).

[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): Indirectly associated with "Eruyt Village", the theme of her eponymous home. It's a sad, soothing theme to match Fran's otherwise calm demeanor, but also hearkening back to the home she's left behind forever.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak): Her Quickenings are [Feral Strike](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HavingABlast), [Whip Kick](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupernaturalMartialArts), and [Shatterheart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnIcePerson), but they need skill and luck to chain together. In *Revenant Wings*, she has Gaze of the Void as her new Quickening, which is a [Dispel Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DispelMagic) effect on all foes.

[Master of None](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfNone): Like Vaan, she is an all-around styled character, but with all her stats being all-around low. In fact, stats-wise, she probably is the worst character of your party, being overshadowed by everyone else. The *International Zodiac Job System* rebalances her stats by giving her the best Vitality score (whereas she was second to last in the original release), and altering other stats among the other controllable characters. She remains average, but the gap is not as wide as before.
[Ms. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsExposition): Fran is very well informed about the lore and mystical goings-on of Ivalice and it is often up to her to info-dump these things to the party.

[Ms. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice): Along with the rest of her race. She's got a shapely body covered up by what can best be described as a [wire bikini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChainmailBikini), and it's quite form-fitting too.
[Multi-Melee Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiMeleeMaster): Noted to be a master of weapons. Not that you can tell from [her stats](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAbility).

[No Sense of Humor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoSenseOfHumor): Averted. Despite being [The Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoic), [The Fair Folk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFairFolk), and a [Really 700 Years Old](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Really700YearsOld) all rolled into one, she can be quite humorous, in a sly, blunt way.
QUOTE **Fran:** Then it's settled. We should leave before the Marquis notices she's missing, like proper kidnappers.
[Older Sidekick](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlderSidekick): Is Balthier's partner, but in practice, she often just follows him. She is also 50+, while he is 22.

[Older Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlderThanTheyLook): She appears to be a young woman, but she's old enough that she left home fifty years prior to the story. [Viera's age far slower than humans](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustifiedTrope), so she's probably young by Viera standards anyway. It's unclear whether it's any indication, but she gets somewhat offended when Vaan asks for her age.
[Only One Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyOneName): As with all Viera.

[Our Elves Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurElvesAreDifferent): The Viera are elves in practice, a magic-inclined race living isolated from the world. They just happen to have bunny ears instead of traditional pointed ones.
[Outlaw Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutlawCouple): With Balthier as a pair of Sky Pirates that travel Ivalice. However it's not fully clear if they're in a romantic or platonic relationship.

[Persona Non Grata](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PersonaNonGrata): Most of Eruyt Village snubs her. The Golmore Jungle takes things a step further by blocking her path and sending the Elder Wyrm after her.
[She-Fu](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SheFu): If you unlock the Brawler license and have her fight unarmed and shield-less, one of her two attacks is a somersault kick.
[Sky Pirate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkyPirate): Along with Balthier, she forms a duo of two famous Sky Pirates.

tropeName: Sliding Scale of Gameplay and Story Integration
tropeNotes: [Sliding Scale of Gameplay and Story Integration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlidingScaleOfGameplayAndStoryIntegration): After Judge Ghis put the Dawn shard in the ship's engine on the Dreadnought Leviathan, the rising Mist makes Fran go berserk, and she single-handedly gets rid of the guards assigned to keep your party captive. This is reflected in the following battle, in which Fran will be stuck into the Berserk status.

[Statuesque Stunner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatuesqueStunner): Although not as tall as she appears at first glance because of her ears and stilettos. In reality, she's slightly taller than Balthier, which still puts her over six feet.
[Sugar-and-Ice Personality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SugarAndIcePersonality): But more amiable than usual for the trope. She's just very quiet.

[The Reliable One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReliableOne): For a fanservice character who's on the more minor side of the main cast, she's one of the most useful throughout the course of the game, [average fighting stats notwithstanding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfNone). She saves members of the main cast not once, not twice, but three times,  (SPOILER) rescues her sister , indirectly rescues Basch, and is often the one the party turns to for advice, such as directing  (SPOILER)  the princess to those who can help her with the Sun Cryst , translating texts, or just beating up a bunch of guards that have captured everyone.
[Status Effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusEffects): Her specialty in *Revenant Wings*. She has Blinding Arrow, Sleep Arrow, Silencing Arrow, and more.
[The Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoic): Generally quiet, dignified, and level-headed. However, there are a few moments in the game where her cool cracks a little.
[Thong of Shielding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThongOfShielding): Her, um, let's call them "pants" leave little to the imagination.
[Token Nonhuman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenNonhuman): The only non-Hume of the party.
[Unusual Ears](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnusualEars): Large and tall rabbit ears.

[Verbal Tic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VerbalTic): She has a slight but noticeable (and *[consistent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OohMeAccentsSlipping)*) lisp due to her overbite. [Superlative Dubbing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/SugarWiki/SuperlativeDubbing) turns this into a sexy voice—she *feels* inherently different from the Hume party members, yet is always friendly and understanding.

tropeName: What the Hell Is That Accent?
tropeNotes: [What the Hell Is That Accent?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellIsThatAccent): Like other Vieras, Fran has a *very* weird accent to convey her otherworldliness from the rest of the party. According to the creators, it's supposed to be Icelandic.

[Wrench Wench](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WrenchWench): She is noted to be as handy with a wrench as she is with a sword, of course, comes up  (SPOILER) in the ending where she and Balthier stay behind to fix Bahamut's glossair rings .

tropeName: You Are a Credit to Your Race
tropeNotes:
[You Are a Credit to Your Race](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreACreditToYourRace): Averted. Balthier mentions it, but is clearly joking. This doesn't spare him from a well-placed comeback.
QUOTE **Balthier:** *(notices Vaan staring at Fran)* Not many Viera where you come from, thief?  
**Vaan:** It's Vaan. *(looks to Fran)* Sorry.  
**Balthier:** Well, Fran is special, in that she'd deign to partner with a Hume.  
**Fran:** Oh? Like a sky pirate who chooses to steal through the sewers?

[You Can't Go Home Again](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouCantGoHomeAgain): When she does eventually return to visit the Viera village, it's implied they miss her, but Fran holds this opinion; She can no longer hear "the Green Word", i.e. the voice of the forest. Even though her fellows insist the forest wants her to stay, she doesn't believe it. She's made her choice and must live with it, for better or worse.

[Bare-Fisted Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BareFistedMonk): When he first joins the party, he fights barehanded because he came out of imprisonment wearing nothing but pants. This changes midway through Barheim Passage.
[Baritone of Strength](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BaritoneOfStrength): His voice is deep and commanding, befitting an experienced soldier such as himself.
[Beard of Sorrow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeardOfSorrow): When in prison, but he trims it to a reasonable length once he escapes.

[The Big Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBigGuy): As the heroic war veteran and military captain, he has the greatest military experience. When Ashe seeks advice on deviousness she asks the sky pirates, but when it comes to military/politics/morality, she asks Basch.
[Blemished Beauty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlemishedBeauty): His scars don't keep him from being [Mr. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrFanservice).

[Bookends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bookends): The story starts when Basch's [Evil Twin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilTwin), Gabranth, impersonates him to kill the King of Dalmasca, therefore enabling Archadia to subjugate Dalmasca. The ending has Basch impersonating Gabranth to stop the breakout of a world war, restoring Dalmasca's independence.

[Boring, but Practical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoringButPractical): His attack animations are all pretty basic stuff with little to no acrobatics, but come out very quickly and would actually really hurt if done in real life.

[Cain and Abel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel): He is the Abel to Gabranth's Cain, though Basch is the older twin. However, it can be said that Basch was originally the *Cain* figure, as he abandoned his family back home while Gabranth had to take up the reins as head of the family. It's only later on, when Basch and Gabranth joined their respective sides, that the role was reversed.

[The Captain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCaptain): Before the main events of the game, he was a captain in Dalmasca's military. In the Japanese version his rank was [General](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourStarBadass).

[Clear My Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClearMyName): Everyone thinks he killed Raminas, but he's innocent. He wants to change that first part.  (SPOILER) Subverted in the end. By the end of the game the public at large still thinks he's dead and guilty, and the people who know he's alive also know he's innocent.
[Declaration of Protection](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeclarationOfProtection): If you want to hurt Ashe, you'll have to step over Basch's limp corpse to get to her.
[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): Basch will stop at nothing to protect Ashe and see Dalmasca restored. **Nothing**.
[El Cid Ploy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElCidPloy): In the ending, he pulls this for  (SPOILER) Gabranth, impersonating him as Larsa's bodyguard to uphold the new peace they've managed to create.

[Failure Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailureKnight): As  (SPOILER) Gabranth  notes, everything and everyone Basch has ever tried to protect has been destroyed or disgraced. He's well aware of it, too.
[A Father to His Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFatherToHisMen): He was this as his scenes with Reks could attest to, which made it that much harder on the poor boy when he died.
[Flaming Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlamingSword): Basch's Flame Purge quickening conjures a circle of swords made out of the fire to shoot at enemies as projectiles.

[Genius Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusBruiser): Formerly being a respected war hero he knew a lot of powerful people in Dalmascan politics, and was privy to quite a lot of the inner workings of government and diplomacy. Once she begins to trust him again Ashe regularly asks his council on matters of statecraft.
[Good Scars, Evil Scars](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodScarsEvilScars): He has a scar above his eye. The manga establishes he got it in a duel with  (SPOILER) Gabranth .
[Horse Archer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HorseArcher): He's one in the opening movie, being mounted on a Chocobo.
[Hunk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hunk): Got the muscles and temperament to show it.

[Immigrant Patriotism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImmigrantPatriotism): Basch was originally not a Dalmascan, but rather from a country called Landis, which was conquered by Archadia years ago. He escaped to Dalmasca because he didn't want to see another state suffer the same fate as his country did.

[Impersonating the Evil Twin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpersonatingTheEvilTwin):  (SPOILER)  At the climax of the game, he briefly impersonates Gabranth using Strahl's voice changer to call for a ceasefire between Archadia and the Resistance. He later impersonates him permanently when he moves to Archades to become a Judge Magister.

[Intergenerational Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntergenerationalFriendship): He is the second-oldest member of the party and the oldest looking one, as [Fran does not show her age](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Really700YearsOld).
[Knight in Shining Armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightInShiningArmor): Lacks the actual armor, but is this in practice, a stalwart and noble protector of morality.

[Knight, Knave, and Squire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightKnaveAndSquire): The knight to Vaan's squire and Balthier's knave. The moral and honorable Basch takes to Vaan as he did to his late brother Reks, a knight that served under his command, and encourages him to learn both from Balthier and himself.
[Lady and Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyAndKnight): He takes up his role as Ashe's protector and muscle per Vossler's request after he lays defeated.

[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): The cutscene-specific "Basch's Reminiscence", which plays as he recounts Reks and King Raminas' deaths by Gabranth. It's a somber, melancholic theme that uses some notes from "White Room", the theme that plays during Vaan's own recollection of Reks in his catatonia, as well as in Mt. Bur-Omisace after Judge Bergan's rampage until the defeat of the Rank VII Mark Fafnir.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak): His Quickenings are [Fulminating Darkness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KamehameHadoken), [Ruin Impendent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupernaturalMartialArts), and [Flame Purge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StormOfBlades), but they need skill and luck to chain together. He gets a new one for *Revenant Wings*, Apocalypse Shield, which nullifies all damage for the party.

[Mighty Glacier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightyGlacier): Physically strongest of the party (with Vaan), but has low speed and, like Balthier, [pitiful magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicallyIneptFighter) skills.
[Missing Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissingMom): She died sometimes after he left for the war.
[Mr. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrFanservice): His imprisonment's "[attire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoGoEnslavement)".
[Navel Window](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NavelWindow): His shirt is slightly cut in the middle to show his abs.

[The Paladin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePaladin): In *Revenant Wings*, it's his character class, and thus he wields large swords, wears heavy armor, and a combination of light-based offensive attacks and defense-based support magic.

[Pull the Thread](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PullTheThread): Larsa practically invokes the trope by name regarding Basch and Ashe. The world thinks Basch dead, but someone kept him alive in secret. There are reasons for that, and his survival will really shake up the status quo as word gets around.
[Purple Prose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PurpleProse): More so than any of the other party members, he tends to be very eloquent.
[Rummage Sale Reject](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RummageSaleReject): Is that a *potholder* under his vest?
[The Quiet One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheQuietOne): Unless he has something to say, he'll go along without a peep.
[Shell-Shocked Veteran](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShellShockedVeteran): Though a high-functioning war veteran, he's clearly traumatized by what he's been through.

[Shirtless Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShirtlessScene): When he appears again after the two-year timeskip, he wears pants and nothing else. He loots a dead soldier's clothing in Barheim Passage and later changes into a civilian one upon returning to Rabanastre.
[Supporting Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupportingLeader): In story, to Ashe since he's older and more experienced; in gameplay and presentation, to Vaan and for the same reason.
[War Is Hell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarIsHell): "If I could protect but one person from war's horror, I would bear any shame. I would bear it proudly."
[Accent Upon The Wrong Syllable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AccentUponTheWrongSyllable): Her name's spelled identically, but it's pronounced "ASH" in the English dub and "ah-SHEH" in the Japanese dub.

[Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionGirl): Ashe is just as capable in battle as any of the other party members, and the one with the stats and personality most inclined for engaging in melee combat. The party first meets her fighting a squad of Imperials and not backing down.

[Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero): Somewhat, during the story's early stages - while she cared for Dalmasca, she wasn't the most level-headed member of the group before her [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment).
[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS): Two of them, the Sword of Kings and the Treaty Blade. Both also function as [Swords of Plot Advancement](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SwordOfPlotAdvancement).
[Break the Cutie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakTheCutie): She's a widow while still in her teens. Unlike most political marriages, both Ashe and Rasler truly loved each other.

[Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment): Learns to do what is best for Dalmasca and its people as opposed to blindly chasing revenge against the Empire, which would probably get her kingdom destroyed and herself killed. Also becomes more heroic and sociable as time goes on; when you first meet her she's a bit of a hardcase and doesn't really trust the other party members.

[Chickification](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Chickification): In the manga. Her introduction in the game establishes her as a [Lady of War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfWar), where she cuts down an imperial soldier and stands defiant against several more before leaping away. In the manga, she's actively fleeing from her attackers and struggles to defend herself, and is nearly helpless in subsequent battles.

[The Chosen One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChosenOne):  (SPOILER) As the next Dynast-King by the Occuria. 
QUOTE  (SPOILER) "Fear not, princess of Dalmasca. We Occuria have chosen you, and you alone."

[Commonality Connection](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CommonalityConnection): Vaan and Ashe have this with their extremely similar experience during the war with Archades, and it's because of this they can see the ghost of their lost loved ones in the Tomb of Raithwall. In the climax of the game, it's this bond that  (SPOILER)  allows Vaan to [save Ashe from herself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JumpingOffTheSlipperySlope) .

[Crusading Widow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrusadingWidow): One of the defining motivations Ashe has is the death of her husband and father and is haunted by the ghost of her husband at multiple points during the game. This drives her to vengeful extremes, dehumanizing the Empire and resistant to a peaceful resolution for her people.
[Defrosting the Ice Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefrostingTheIceQueen): She's rude and abrasive at first, but gradually warms up and accepts the party as friends and allies.

[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): Just listen to her Quickening quotes:
QUOTE "I must endure." / "I must believe." / "I must be strong."

[Dramatic Wind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DramaticWind): Especially when performing her Quickenings and casting magic. More noticeable when fighting outside, but even inside her clothing tends to flutter, just less so.
[Fairytale Wedding Dress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FairytaleWeddingDress): She wore one in her wedding. Combine princess and true love and it fits the ideal.

[Fallen Princess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FallenPrincess): At the start of the game, Ashe's father and husband are killed and she has to fake her death in order to avoid becoming a puppet or incite a bloody rebellion doomed to failure in her name. A fair portion of the early game revolves around Ashe needing to prove her lineage and reclaim her throne so that she may be able to broker peace with Emperor Gramis and stop Ondore's rebellion before Rozzaria steps in.

[The Final Temptation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFinalTemptation): Atop the Pharos, Ashe is left with the ghost of Rasler tempting her to betray her character development and take revenge on the Empire - with extra prompting from Gabranth - and almost considers it, but Vaan helps her realize she'd be regressing and she reasserts the group's intention to destroy the Sun Cryst.
[Glass Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlassCannon): Has high magick and strength stats, but her HP is low.
[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): Introduces the mechanic when you first meet her and she calls herself Amalia.

[The Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHero): While Vaan is the viewpoint character, and contrary to Balthier's claims, Ashe is the one whom the narrative revolves around; it's her desires and actions that motivate the plot while the others accompany her as allies, and most of the antagonists concern themselves with her unless they have a personal connection with someone else in the party. This is most notable with the trailers and marketing for the *Zodiac Age* remaster, which focus on Ashe's role in the story foremost and positions Vaan and Balthier as secondary protagonists.

[Heroes Prefer Swords](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroesPreferSwords): Swords of various different styles, even when she uses [bombs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowDownTheBomblet) in the sequel she still has a sword in her artwork. She also likes her shield. Even her unarmed animation has her putting up her left hand like she's got one on there.
[The High Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHighQueen):  (SPOILER) In the epilogue, Penelo notes in her letter to Larsa that Ashe will be crowned queen in a month.
[Insistent Terminology](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsistentTerminology): She does *not* lead a "insurgence". She leads a "Resistance!"

[Lady of Black Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfBlackMagic): Poised and has the highest MP and Magick Power growth rates in the party. Even her Quickenings have an air of grace to them. No wonder *[Final Fantasy Record Keeper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyRecordKeeper)* has her as the main [Black Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMage) of her Realm.
[Lady of War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfWar): Even in the heat of battle, Ashe remains poised and graceful.
[Last of His Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHisKind): Since her brothers all died before her and her father was assassinated, Ashe is the last of Raithwall's bloodline.

[The Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLeader): She's the one that sets the agenda for the hero party. The other party members tag along with her for various reasons and offer her support and advice.

[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): "Ashe's Theme". It has two sections, both used at different points in the game for emphasis:
    - The first section is more mysterious and mystical-sounding, ending with a grandiose flourish. This represents Ashe as a princess, her affinity with magic and her ties to Dalmasca's founding lineage. In-game, besides a few cutscenes, it plays at the entrance to the Ancient City of Giruvegan, since it's connected to Ashe and the Occuria. - The second section is darker and ominous, more threatening and intimidating. This ties to Ashe's desire for revenge against the Empire, and her rage to the point of using the nethicite in retaliation. In the original release, it was the theme of the bonus dungeon "Subterra", which is perpetually darkened and filled with hostile entities.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak): Her Quickenings are [Nordswain's Glow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightEmUp), [Heaven's Wrath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicMissileStorm), and [Maelstrom's Bolt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe), but they need skill and luck to chain together. Her new Quickening in *Revenant Wings* is Empyrean's Edict, which prevents all foes from summoning espers.
[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): Wielding a sword, casting magic, and summoning espers.

[Meaningful Echo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulEcho): Dropping into the Barheim Passage, Balthier berates Vaan for insisting on distrusting Basch over Reks' death by saying "What is done is done", something we see Vaan has taken to heart later, as he forgives Basch and finally realizes he's not responsible for Reks' death.  (SPOILER) Atop the Pharos, Ashe repeats the same line to Gabranth, her father's killer, to complete her [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment), having her finally come to terms with the fact that revenge is an empty motivation, and would ultimately bring harm to herself and her people.

[Morality Chain Beyond the Grave](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoralityChainBeyondTheGrave): Rasler's ghost appears as a [Spirit Advisor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpiritAdvisor) to drive her forward on her quest to restore Dalmasca  (SPOILER) such as convincing her not to use the Sword of Kings to destroy the Dawn Shard and leading her into Giruvegan to meet the Occuria. After it is revealed that his ghost is only an Occurian-made illusion, Ashe decides against using nethicite to destroy the Empire because the real Rasler she loved would never use such catastrophic means for revenge .

[Ms. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice): In the game's manga adaptation. She's the subject of a [Panty Shot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PantyShot), a [bathing scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShowerScene), a [shot of her half-naked rear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MaleGaze), and there's a full-frontal scene of her nude with [Barbie Doll Anatomy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarbieDollAnatomy).
[Navel Window](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NavelWindow): Her outfit shows off her navel.
[Perfectly Arranged Marriage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PerfectlyArrangedMarriage): With Rasler; they joke about how people only see it as a political marriage.

[Pimped-Out Dress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PimpedOutDress): Her wedding dress and her funeral dress are suitably fancy for a princess/queen, but surprisingly no fancy Queen or Princess dresses are shown.

[Politically-Active Princess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoliticallyActivePrincess): Zig-zagged. At first, she tries to take Rabanastre by force. Later, she attempts to reclaim her kingdom by bargaining with [The Empire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmpire) and other factions for most of the game. Although she's a [Warrior Princess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarriorPrincess) and would rather fight against the Archadians, she slowly understands that the easiest way to avoid bloodshed is to take the diplomatic route.

[The Poorly Chosen One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePoorlyChosenOne):  (SPOILER)  Which turns out to be a good thing. The Occuria wanted her to destroy Archadia and remove any trace of Venat's influence. Ultimately Ashe decided revenge wasn't worth it and destroys the Sun-Cryst to end the Occuria's influence over Ivalice.

[Pretty Princess Powerhouse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrettyPrincessPowerhouse): Don't let the fact she's royalty fool you, Ashe has survived in the resistance for two years and can handle herself in a fight. Her [Establishing Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment) is to cut down an Imperial and basically shout "[Bring It](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BringIt)" to three more advancing on her.

[Pyrrhic Victory](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PyrrhicVictory): Ultimately realizes she's setting herself up for this.  (SPOILER) She could take the power of the Sun-Cryst and use deifacted nethicite to fight Archadia, but it would entirely betray the ideals and principles of the kingdom she's been fighting for, and at that point her cause will be truly lost .
[Revenge Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RevengeBeforeReason): She treads this path for a very long time until she takes Vaan's example to fight for what's right rather than for vengeance.

[Royal Brat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalBrat): Early on, between being a [Fallen Princess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FallenPrincess), a widow, and vengeful against the Empire that did both, Ashe can be haughty, proud and quick to dismiss those below her station.
QUOTE **Basch:** You've met Amalia?

QUOTE **Vaan:** I've met nicer people.

[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): Her defining trope more than anything else, Ashe takes her position as Princess very seriously and is fully committed to the political responsibilities that it entails.
[Stripperiffic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperiffic): You'd expect something [more practical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExposedToTheElements) on royalty, wouldn't you?

[Spare to the Throne](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpareToTheThrone): If you pay attention to the NPC conversations, you will find out that Ashe was the youngest of nine siblings with eight older brothers who have all died from war or sickness.
[Spell My Name with a "The"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpellMyNameWithAThe): Sometimes referred to by Basch and Vossler as "The Lady Ashe".

[Star Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StarPower): All three of Ashe's quickenings draw power from the stars, Nordswain's Glow drawing on the Big Dipper, Heaven's Wrath on shooting stars and Maelstrom's Bolt on the energy of an electrical storm in space.
[Time Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeMaster): She is officially a Time Mage in the sequel.

[Tragic Keepsake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicKeepsake): She still wears her wedding ring and also wears Rasler's on her middle finger. She [reluctantly gives Rasler's ring to Balthier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeddingRingRemoval) as compensation for him and Fran accompanying her on her journey until he finds "something more valuable",  (SPOILER) and she does not put it back on when it's returned to her in the epilogue .

[Unscrupulous Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnscrupulousHero): She spends most of the game focused on gaining nethicite, with her ultimate goal being using it to destroy the Archadian Empire to avenge her husband and restore her kingdom. [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment) sees her gaining scruples.
[Bodyguard Betrayal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodyguardBetrayal): He's Ashe's protector until Basch steps in, and then he sells her out.

[The Captain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCaptain): His official title is "Captain" even as he leads the resistance against the Empire and personally steps onto the battlefield to command them. It's a holdover from his days in the Dalmascan militia where he held the rank.

[Climax Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClimaxBoss): You can really *feel* the emotional intensity when you're forced to fight him. The conflict effectively serves to close Act 1 of the game and shifts the narrative considerably.

[Disc-One Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneFinalBoss): His boss fight comes with the first affirmation of Ashe preferring to retaliate against Archades using the Dawn Shard, which he knows very well could endanger Dalmasca and its citizens' well-being, as well as preceding the destruction of the 7th Imperial Fleet, the Dreadnought Leviathan, and the death of one of the Judge Magisters, all of which effectively close what constitutes the game's "Act I". His betrayal is also a prime example of someone who fights for Dalmasca proving themselves untrustworthy to the main party in favor of siding with the Empire for a bloodless conflict, even if does end with Ashe as another puppet for Vayne, showcasing more of the game's approach to [Gray-and-Gray Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrayAndGrayMorality) and how neither side of the war is truly good or evil.

[Establishing Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment): Right at the very beginning. When he and Basch are searching for survivors of the Dalmascan escort for the King, Vossler is indifferent towards a foot soldier (namely, Reks)'s injury and urges Basch to move on, while Basch is more attentive. This quickly establishes the two men's personalities: Basch is a caring [father to his men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFatherToHisMen) who puts what is good above all else, while Vossler is more pragmatic.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Of Lando Calrissian, as a [Regretful Traitor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RegretfulTraitor) to the heroes who delivers them to the Empire while still fighting for what he thinks is a good cause. Lando's more benevolent traits [are passed over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DecompositeCharacter) to Marquis Ondore.
[Face–Heel Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceHeelTurn): He turns on the party and sides with the Empire, though it's not as clear-cut as "he's actually evil".

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): To Basch, given their friendship despite coming from different stations in life. Taken further when, after Basch's absolute loyalty to Ashe is proven, Vossler himself becomes a traitor.

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): Vaan, once he returns to Rabanastre after escaping the Nalbina Dungeons with the party, is charged with delivering Vossler's sword to the Resistance's secret meeting place in Lowtown, right when they are discussing Reks' testimony about the king's assassination. Basch, the traitor even the Resistance is having a hard time believing in, welcomes Vaan politely and treats him like an equal. Vossler, the "true" son of Dalmasca, wrestles his sword out of Vaan's grip rudely and treats him, a citizen of the kingdom he's sworn to protect, with cold dismissal. While the interaction is small, Vaan later forgives and accepts Basch as being framed by the Archadian Empire, while Vossler betrays his charge's trust and sides with the Empire.
