    - There are two lines from him that hint at his eventual betrayal; at the Dreadnought Leviathan, he'll mention to Basch that in order to get Ashe to cooperate, they need to have her "meet the reality of the situation", a perfect summation of his real perception of Dalmasca's current state. Once they escape to Bhujerba and he takes his leave, he tells Ashe to trust Basch, as his loyalty to Dalmasca is no less than his own. [Exact Words](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExactWords) are at play here: their loyalty to Dalmasca really is unshaken, in Vossler's case maybe too much so, and bear in mind that Ashe is still coming down from thinking of Basch as a "traitor".

[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): Joins the party as a Guest twice (at the Leviathan and before the first trek through the Yensa Sandsea all the way until after the Tomb of Raithwall).

[Hero Antagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroAntagonist): Without a doubt, after his [Face–Heel Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceHeelTurn) because it makes him antagonistic to Ashe and the main heroes but his goal remains the same. He just has different ideas about reaching it.

[Knight in Sour Armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightInSourArmor): Deconstructed. Vossler's priority is and always has been the welfare of Dalmasca and its freedom, but the conflict has essentially diminished his hopes for the latter, resulting in his brusque, abrasive behavior by the time Basch returns. He's *so* beaten down by the war against Archades, in fact, he strikes a deal with Judge Ghis to restore Ashe to power and leave the kingdom unharmed, yet still under Imperial law, in exchange for the Dawn Shard. Basically, he fights for a good cause, but is not optimistic about the results.
[La Résistance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaResistance): He's one of the leaders of the resistance against the Empire.

[Moral Myopia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoralMyopia): A very gray case of this regarding his betrayal. Vossler has his mind set on the restoration of Dalmasca first and foremost. When Ashe reveals her intentions as revenge first, Dalmasca second, Vossler ends up siding with the Archadians. There's also a second factor in his betrayal in that the resistance's war from his perspective seems to be growing more futile as the days pass; and by allying with the Archadians, Vayne will actually restore Dalmasca's independence. In his favor, there's a fair chance Vayne may have lived up to his word, and politically it wouldn't have been a dreadful move for Vayne to restore the hearts and minds of the people, even if Ashe is a glorified [Puppet King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuppetKing) to his own ends and means. Finally, going back a bit in the entry, Vossler is also *very* tired of fighting and believes his betrayal to be a bloodless end to the revolution.
[My Country, Right or Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyCountryRightOrWrong): He puts the wellbeing of Dalmasca first and foremost.

[Sacrificial Lion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SacrificialLion): His death and Ashe's refusal to accept his bargain with the Empire firmly establishes what her priorities are: vengeance first, Dalmasca second. His betrayal also shakes the game up on a meta level, truly introducing the grey morality of the antagonists and the heroes.
[The Sixth Ranger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSixthRanger): An outsider to your main party of six who helps them from behind the scenes.
[Sixth Ranger Traitor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SixthRangerTraitor): As a floater ally who betrays the protagonists.
[Take Up My Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeUpMySword): Tells Basch to protect Ashe in his stead after his defeat.
[Utopia Justifies the Means](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UtopiaJustifiesTheMeans): Will restore Dalmasca no matter what, even if he must betray her rightful ruler to do it.

[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): He's basically the leader of [La Résistance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaResistance) by the end of the game and the one with the broader scope of things than Vossler.

[The Chessmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChessmaster): Manipulates a lot of events behind the scenes without directly getting his hands dirty. Since he's closely watched by the Empire, he has to be secretive about it to avoid his true plans being discovered.
[Classy Cane](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClassyCane): Walks with an ornate cane.
[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): He's old, but still a good player in the political field.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy):
    - With Bhujerba serving as the game's analogue to Cloud City (a nation who stands neutral in the central conflict but ultimately sides with the Resistance), Ondore holds Lando Calrissian's charge as its ruler. Although he also [shares](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DecompositeCharacter) the role of Lando's expy with Vossler. - He also takes on a similar role to Mon Mothma, being a secret leader of [La Résistance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaResistance) who is unable to directly aid the protagonists in their quest.
[Inevitable Mutual Betrayal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InevitableMutualBetrayal): Half the plot hinges on the fact that Bhujerba will be going to war with Archadia soon if nothing is done to stop it.

[Know When to Fold 'Em](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnowWhenToFoldEm): He made a deal for Bhujerba to become Archadia's vassal to spare it from war devastation that Dalmasca suffered after it fell, but still works behind-the-scenes as part of the Resistance to undermine Archadia.
[La Résistance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaResistance): Not a member, but a close ally. After Vossler's death he effectively becomes the leader of it.

[Minor Major Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MinorMajorCharacter): Only several actual appearances but, as both the [Narrator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Narrator) and the ally of [La Résistance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaResistance), he's pretty important as far as characters go.
[Narrator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Narrator): Major events are shown as part of the Marquis' [historical accounts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FramingDevice).
[Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute): He's an advisor/parental figure to Ashe, who calls him her uncle.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): He's the leader of Bhujerba and one of the few politically powerful figures who wants to *do* something about Archadia.
[Silver Fox](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SilverFox): He's got grey hair and he's quite handsome. Just take a gander at his picture!

[Unreliable Narrator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnreliableNarrator): Infamously so, he's known for publicly lying and concealing the truth for assorted political reasons. There's a reason "Don't listen to Ondore's lies" is a [Memetic Mutation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MemeticMutation).

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): A meta example, he was a minor supporting character before [Norio Wakamoto](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/NorioWakamoto) was cast. His vocal performance considerably endeared Al-Cid to the developers and netted him a bigger part in the game.
[Carpet of Virility](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CarpetOfVirility): His chest hair is magnificent to behold.
[The Casanova](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCasanova): His special abilities in *Tactics A2* let him help and power up the girls on the team.
[The Charmer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCharmer): He's very flirtatious and flattering with ladies, including Ashe.
[Chick Magnet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChickMagnet): From the looks of it, none of the other girls mind the flirting.
[Cool Shades](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolShades): Even in Final Fantasy, he's got to have them.
[Dashing Hispanic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DashingHispanic): His design and Spanish accent in the English dub clearly invoke this.

[Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam): He's positively understated among [Wakamoto](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/NorioWakamoto)'s other roles, but his sensuality and gesticulations set him apart from most of the cast.

[One-Steve Limit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneSteveLimit): Played with — this game gives us both Al-Cid and Dr. Cid. [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod) has clarified that Dr. Cid is the official "Cid" of the game, while Al-Cid is just another character who happens to also be named Cid.

[Overrated and Underleveled](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OverratedAndUnderleveled): In *Tactics A2*, he cannot change classes. He is the *only* unit who cannot change classes. Even Vaan and Penelo, who also join with unique classes, are able to class change. This means he can't use anything other than guns, can't ever learn a secondary skillset other than Item, and can never learn any Support or Reaction abilities.
[Pretty Boy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrettyBoy): A *very* pretty one.

[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): He gets involved with the events of the game and does what he can to try and prevent another outbreak of war. He's not even the true/direct heir to Rozarria, but implied to be one of many.
[Sharp-Dressed Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SharpDressedMan): His sense of grooming is impeccable, and he's a smooth-talking casanova to boot.
[Sexy Secretary](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SexySecretary): He's always *accompanied* by [one](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheVoiceless) whose main job seems to be holding his sunglasses.

[Spare to the Throne](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpareToTheThrone): While he is of [Royal Blood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalBlood) and a prince, he claims to be "one of many" and does not seem to be in the direct line of succession.
[Tall, Dark, and Handsome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TallDarkAndHandsome): Though his height is unknown.
[Tuxedo and Martini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TuxedoAndMartini): Tactics A2 reveals that he is this sort of Spy for Rozzaria with the unique Agent job.
[The Spymaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSpymaster): Claims to have "little birds" who tell him things. We never fully find out what that means, but Al-Cid clearly has connections.

[The Wise Prince](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheWisePrince): Some of his *activities* aside, he's a very clever man and a competent politician. When he first meets Ashe he bring up important matters for her to consider, and when the party's shown determined to seek out the deifacted nethicite, he makes important points such as needing to *find* what they're looking for.
[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): He's seeking to make up for a great sin he did in the past.

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast):  (SPOILER)  "I, Judge Magister, condemn you to oblivion!" Doubles as some shades of [Dying as Yourself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DyingAsYourself) since it's a nod to a past he'd tried to leave behind him.
[Bald of Authority](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BaldOfAuthority): The bald leader of the sky pirates.
[Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton): Much like Balthier, but more overt. Try bringing up nethicite around him and see how he takes it.

[Dark and Troubled Past](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkAndTroubledPast):  (SPOILER) He's really Judge Zecht, the sixth Judge Magister of Archadia charged with using the Midlight Shard at Nabudis to see the power of deifacted nethicite. Horrified by his own unwitting actions, he vowed to never let such destruction be unleashed again, and forsook the empire, his title, and his name, to become a force in the resistance.
[Death Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathSeeker): One of his aides, Elza, claims Reddas has been looking for a time and place to die all along. All things considered, she may be on to something.

tropeName: Did You Just Flip Off Cthulhu?
tropeNotes:
[Did You Just Flip Off Cthulhu?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidYouJustFlipOffCthulhu): Though he doesn't do it directly, he makes his opinion of  (SPOILER) the Occuria  clear.
QUOTE **Reddas:** Would you like to know the best use of nethicite? Will or nill, I'll tell you. You pick it up, and throw it away.
[Dual Wielding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWielding): Uses [Cool Swords](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolSword), the Chirijiraden and the Ninja Knife.

[Dynamic Entry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DynamicEntry): His first appearance on-screen has him attempting a jumping double-sword strike on Basch, then simply noting the group are not Archadeans before apologizing in a laidback "shit happens" way.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): To Balthier, in lots of spoileriffic ways. Had they each made some slightly different choices, they might have switched places in the narrative.  (SPOILER) They're both former members of the Archadian Empire, Judges even (though Reddas was a Judge *Magister*), who went rogue and abandoned their former lives and names when the Empire's warmongering went too far for them. However, Balthier would rather have nothing to do with the Archadia and nethicite and gets roped into things by chance, while Reddas protactively seeks to stop Cid from using nethicite on the scale of Nabudis and will fight to do it. Balthier went rogue to reclaim his freedom and became a sky pirate with little higher ambition than that, while Reddas went rogue to resist the Empire, which included becoming the de facto leader of Balfonheim and an ally of Ondore.
[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): For the last dungeon of the game.

[Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD):  (SPOILER)  The destruction of Nabudis  caused a [My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone) [Heel Realization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelRealization), and he's never fully recovered from it.
[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice):  (SPOILER) He sacrifices himself to destroy the Sun Cryst before the mist it spews causes chaos over Ivalice.
[Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam): Surpassed only by Doctor Cid.
[Manly Facial Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManlyFacialHair): Has a short-cropped beard to emphasize his rugged look.

[Memetic Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MemeticBadass): [In-Universe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InUniverse).  (SPOILER) Reddas's death, which involved destroying the Sun-Cryst with the Sword of Kings, ended up redeeming himself, screwing over the Occuria, screwing over Vayne, and basically setting off a nuke in his face at the same time. The Way Stone that brought the party to the top no longer works afterward, implying that *the top floor doesn't even exist anymore*... but a handful of Balfonheim residents think that this death wasn't fitting enough for him.
[My Greatest Failure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGreatestFailure):  (SPOILER)  The destruction of Nalbina using the Midlight shard was the last straw for him and caused him to abandon the Empire.

[One-Man Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneManArmy): You know someone has beaten you inside Draklor when you explore the facility and find it strewn with the bodies of Imperial soldiers. Reddas' doing.
[The Paladin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePaladin): In the [Zodiac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpdateRerelease) versions he also casts [Holy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HolyHandGrenade) and Arise.
[Pirate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Pirate) and [Sky Pirate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkyPirate): He is called a pirate of both the sea and sky.
[Real Men Wear Pink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RealMenWearPink): A literal example. His hot pink shorts stand out even in a cast dressed in all manner of bizarre clothing options.
[Redemption Equals Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionEqualsDeath):  (SPOILER) He ultimately redeems himself at the cost of his life.
[Shell-Shocked Veteran](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShellShockedVeteran): He's carrying a lot of guilt and trauma for what he did in the past.

[The Sixth Ranger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSixthRanger): The 3rd and final one to be met in-story.
    - [11th-Hour Ranger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EleventhHourRanger): He doesn't join the party until the penultimate dungeon.

[Small Role, Big Impact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallRoleBigImpact): You meet him with only a few hours left in the game, not counting time spent on sidequests, but once you find out his past, it turns out he's more influential than some of the people you've seen all game.

[The Ghost](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGhost): You've been hearing people talk about "Reddas" all game, but you never meet him in person until the very end. Even then, you probably don't realize he is the person you've heard of before.
[That Man Is Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThatManIsDead): He cast off his old name to become Reddas some time ago.

[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): You've never heard the name before you met him, but you have definitely heard *of* Reddas all game, and when you find out how you'll look at him very differently.

[Wretched Hive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WretchedHive): Acts as the de facto leader of one, Balfonheim, a pirate port. In his own words, it's "a city of men without countries, pirates of the sea and of the sky. Few are they would fain lay down their lives for a friend, let alone a king."

[Younger Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungerThanTheyLook): Would you believe that he's only *thirty-three*? Then again, it could just be that he shaves his head and his hair colour is naturally white, which wouldn't be out there for Final Fantasy.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): Downplayed. Their roles are still minor in the sequel but it's much more than it was in *XII*. Here, they're helpful allies again and part of a [Friendly Rivalry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendlyRivalry) with Vaan as fellow sky pirates.

[Fragile Speedster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FragileSpeedster): Raz in the sequel. He's *fast* when it comes to moving around the field, but he goes down easy. This carries over from his portrayal in *XII* during the footraces, where he is the fastest of the three of them but most prone to tripping.

[Friendly Rivalry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendlyRivalry): With Vaan and his crew when it comes to collecting auracite. They can be encountered in combat in various areas in the floating islands of Lemures.

[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): For a couple battles in *Revenant Wings*, most notably when they help Vaan and the others fight Ba'Gamnan and his crew to rescue Filo.
[The Gunslinger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGunslinger): In the sequel, Elza uses a gun in combat and functions as a ranged unit.
[Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam): Rikken, in spades. He gets much more of a personality in the sequel and this is mostly what it consists of.

[Non-Action Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionGuy): Both Rikken and Elza are fought as part of the Trial mode in *XII* in an optional battle, leaving Raz out. However, by the time of *Revenant Wings* he now joins the fray as a flying unit.

[Nonstandard Character Design](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonstandardCharacterDesign): Raz is a Bangaa, but he's *much* smaller than the others of his race and gets around by use of a tiny floating platform.
[Pirate Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PirateGirl): Elza is a classic one.
[Pirate Parrot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PirateParrot): Raz has one.
[Stripperiffic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperiffic): Elza. She has short shorts, a bra, and an overcoat that doesn't do much to hide that she isn't wearing much underneath.
[Sword and Fist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SwordAndFist): Rikken wields a sword in battle but his profile in *Revenant Wings* indicates he uses hand-to-hand combat as well.

[Two Guys and a Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TwoGuysAndAGirl): In *Revenant Wings* they form their own sky pirate crew, with Rikken as the actual leader. All three of them are good friends and they're always seen together.

[Unwanted Assistance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwantedAssistance): During one battle in *Revenant Wings*, they are running into an issue with a bunch of Yarhi but they don't want Vaan and the others helping them because Rikken thinks they're trying to steal the auracite first.
[Walking Shirtless Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingShirtlessScene): Rikken in the first game, but he gets a big overcoat for the sequel.
[The Lost Lenore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLostLenore): To Ashe.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): His name is one to Prince Ralse from "Draco and Maria", [the opera from](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShowWithinAShow) *[Final Fantasy VI](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVI)*. Like Ralse, his kingdom is to the east (of Dalmasca).
[Perfectly Arranged Marriage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PerfectlyArrangedMarriage): With Ashe.
[Pretty Boy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrettyBoy): See his face?
[Prince Charmless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrinceCharmless): Appeared to be this during a flashback in the manga adaptation; turns out he was trying to lure out a traitor.

[Sacrificial Lion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SacrificialLion): A brave warrior and loving husband who, without hesitation, leads his new wife's kingdom's army to war in order to defend it from Archadia's advances. He, unfortunately, dies at Nalbina Fortress.
[Spare to the Throne](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpareToTheThrone): Ultimania claims that Rasler is the second prince of Nabradia.
[Stab the Sky](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StabTheSky): Does this in the opening cinematic.
[Warrior Prince](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarriorPrince): He is a prince of a neighboring kingdom who doesn't hesitate to fight alongside Dalmasca on the front lines.
[Big Brother Instinct](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherInstinct): He went to war to protect his brother.
[Chainmail Bikini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChainmailBikini): It's no wonder he died; he's wearing a military issue sports bra and thigh highs with short shorts.

[Decoy Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DecoyProtagonist): At the start of the game one expects him to become the hero, but he gets a knife to the gut barely half an hour in and his younger brother Vaan takes over from that point forward.
[Flower Motifs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlowerMotifs): The Galbana Lily was his favorite flower. Vaan even names his airship after this flower in the sequel.

[Impaled with Extreme Prejudice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpaledWithExtremePrejudice): He was stabbed by Basch (SPOILER) 's brother, Noah/Judge Gabranth  after finding out King Raminas was dead. Unlike what one would expect, he survived that, but died later due to a combination of an extended interrogation and a wound complication.
[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): According to the people who knew him, Reks was very kind and noble.
[Pretty Boy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrettyBoy): As shown by his image.
[Promotion to Parent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PromotionToParent): After his and Vaan's parents died, five years before the main events of the game.

[Sacrificial Lamb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SacrificialLamb): Hand-in-hand with [Decoy Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DecoyProtagonist), Reks exists to die in the introduction and demonstrate clearly this game will not be shy about killing off important characters.
[Tragic Keepsake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicKeepsake): His pendant which Vaan is seen wearing for the entirety of the game.

[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn): He is allowed to survive the attack on Nalbina because the Archadians need a witness to testify it was Basch who killed Raminas. Not knowing it was a frame job, Reks played right into their hands.
[White Void Room](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteVoidRoom): Vaan remembers his brother dying in one as he sat unresponsive in a catatonic state.
[You Remind Me of X](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouRemindMeOfX): Basch said this to Reks that he remind him of his brother, Noah.  (SPOILER)  Basch didn't know that his brother is alive.
[Ambiguous Gender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousGender): Just like Venat, Gerun has no physical gender.

[Ancient Conspiracy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AncientConspiracy):  (SPOILER) The Occuria have been manipulating Ivalice for centuries. Now thanks to Venat and Archadia, their grip is slipping, and they're not happy about that.

[Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton): Flies into a screaming rage at the implication that  (SPOILER) Venat's actions might actually have a point. 
QUOTE **Ashe:**  (SPOILER) But, Venat... Venat is an Occurian. A being like you. 

QUOTE **Gerun:**  (SPOILER) **VENAT IS A HERETIC!!!**

[Big Bad Ensemble](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadEnsemble): Has its own schemes opposing Venat and Vayne.  (SPOILER) It spends 90% of the game slow-walking Ashe into becoming a genocidal tyrant under her thrall, the likes of which would have put Vayne to shame by miles. Additionally, it's its control over Ivalice via the Dalmascan kings that motivated Venat to rebel and bring Archadia to power in the first place, making it indirectly responsible for the conflict of the game.

[Blue-and-Orange Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueAndOrangeMorality):  (SPOILER) Annihilating every man, woman, and child in Archadia is completely justified to them if it rids it of Venat and scours manufactured nethicite from the world so the Occuria can keep humanity under their thumb.

[Crazy-Prepared](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrazyPrepared): It's strongly implied that Venat resorts to the roundabout tactics it does because Gerun has checks and contingencies on nearly all other options.  (SPOILER) For example, when picking a [Chosen One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChosenOne) to be the instrument of her wrath, Gerun actually begins grooming multiple people to its will with the same trick just in case one of them failed.
[Energy Beings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnergyBeings): Appears as a floating specter of light with a shadowed "face".
[General Ripper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeneralRipper):  (SPOILER) The whole "World War" thing Ivalice is heading towards? It doesn't mind, as long as the right people emerge victorious.

[Glamour Failure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlamourFailure):  (SPOILER) Its plan to turn Ashe into a new Dynast-King implodes completely when, in a moment of sheer panic, it starts speaking directly through Rasler's ghost. The apparition had been otherwise silent up until that point, disguising the deception, and when it starts speaking with Gerun’s voice instead of Rasler’s, the jig is up completely.

tropeName: God Save Us from the Queen!
tropeNotes: [God Save Us from the Queen!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodSaveUsFromTheQueen): It wouldn't be a [Yasumi Matsuno](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/YasumiMatsuno) game if this *wasn't* at play somewhere.

[The Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHypocrite): The writings found in  (SPOILER)  the Pharos  claim that  (SPOILER)  The Occuria's immortality made them  much wiser and cold-headed than  (SPOILER)  the mortal races , yet all it takes is Ashe  (SPOILER)  reminding Gerun that Venat is of its kind to get it enraged and order the young princess to not only destroy Venat  but on top of that  (SPOILER)  [commit genocide against the compatriots of Venat's Hume disciples](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisproportionateRetribution) despite the fact that most Archadians don't even *know* Venat *exists* .
[Jerkass Gods](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassGods): It carries high the *[Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/FinalFantasy)* standard of higher beings that are pricks.

[Light Is Not Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightIsNotGood): Gerun's physical form is silver compared with  (SPOILER)  the dark purple of Venat.  However, it's far more prideful and ruder than  (SPOILER) Venat  could ever be.

[Manipulative Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManipulativeBastard):  (SPOILER) It used Raithwal to establish Ocurrian rule over Ivalice and plans to use Ashe to preserve it. Its intent to get Ashe to destroy Archadia and Venat, progressing from subtle manipulation to outright ordering her to do it.

[Non-Action Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionBigBad): Gerun and the Occuria possess great power but prefer to rely on manipulations and never actually attempt to directly intervene beyond that.
[No Gender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoGender): Genderless due to not having a physical body, but has a female-ish voice.
[One-Shot Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneShotCharacter): Appears as itself for less than five minutes, despite having a continuous role throughout the plot of the game.

[Protagonist Journey to Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProtagonistJourneyToVillain):  (SPOILER) Spends the whole game trying to make this happen for Ashe. Fails spectacularly at it because she ultimately realizes what's happening to her.

[Puny Humans](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunyHumans) / [We Are as Mayflies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeAreAsMayflies): Shares this outlook on Humes.
QUOTE " (SPOILER) The Humes ever skew hist'ry's weave. With haste they move through too-short lives. Driven to err by base desires, t'ward waste and wasting on they run. We Occuria light the path for wayward sons of man. "

[Purple Prose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PurpleProse): Gerun speaks in iambic tetrameter, using poetic abbreviations and rhyming couplets to rigidly stick to the meter. Venat, by contrast speaks in iambic *penta*meter, never uses rhyme scheme, and is slightly more free form with her verse, ie: quite [heretical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusBonus) in comparison.

[Shape Shifter Guilt Trip](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShapeShifterGuiltTrip):  (SPOILER) The ghostly image of Rasler that keeps appearing to Ashe over the course of the game is Gerun playing off her grief and rage towards Archadia to get her to acquiesce to genocide. Vaan can also see Gerun's apparition, but to him it looks like his older brother Reks. This is because Gerun is running the same con on him at the same time, grooming Vaan to be its backup Dynast King if Ashe falters.

[Small Role, Big Impact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallRoleBigImpact): Eclipses even Reddas in terms of the screen time:plot importance ratio.  (SPOILER) The meeting with it and the revelations that follow cast a very revealing light on the true goals of Archadia and the villains you've been fighting.

[Take Up My Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeUpMySword): Gerun does this in the most literal sense, giving Ashe the Treaty-Blade so she may become the next Dynast-King and the Occuria's [Chosen One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChosenOne).
QUOTE **Gerun:** The treaty held with kings of old is but a mem'ry, cold and still. 
With you we now shall treat anew, to cut a run for hist'ry's flow. 
Now take this sword, this Treaty-Blade. Occurian seal, mark of your worth. 
Cut deep the Cryst, and seize your Shards. 
Wield Dynast-King's power!  (SPOILER) *Destroy Venat!*
[Top God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TopGod): The king of the Occuria.

[Toxic Friend Influence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ToxicFriendInfluence):  (SPOILER) Ashe doesn't realize the specter of Rasler that's been guiding her all game is a vision of Gerun, and that it is using his memory to manipulate the party.

[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): As all the whited-out entries might have tipped you off. Gerun is a late-game character and the meeting with them reveals a lot of critical plot details.

[Wicked Cultured](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WickedCultured): Speaks in poetic meter, uses highfalutin language and poetic abbreviations such as pow'r and hist'ry, and carries itself with all the dignity of an Elizabethan monarch,  (SPOILER) until you piss it off, which makes its eyes burn with fury and unleashes a shockwave .

[Adaptational Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalVillainy): In the manga, he's much more cruel and manipulative, getting several new scenes that have him [Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog) by taunting those under his command and being more arrogant and cold in his dealings. His charismatic speech to the people of Dalmasca happens off-screen, and when Vayne mentions it later he admits he doubts he managed to instill any loyalty in the peoples' hearts, a far cry from the game where he had them cheering for him.

[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): He's famously one of the most personable and charismatic villains in the series. His [Establishing Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment) is to deliver a speech to the people of Rabanastre that can be summed up as "I know you all hate me and the Empire, but I'm not asking you to love me or even be loyal to me, just to please keep the peace in honor of your departed King, so that we can all try to move on as one people now that the war is over." The speech is so effective that the crowd that was jeering him at the start is applauding him once he's done. Then that night he organizes a feast at the royal palace so that his presence will bait the Resistance into attack, and he routs them and captures or kills most of the combatants.
[Aloof Big Brother](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AloofBigBrother): To Larsa. Everyone comments on how much more powerful Vayne is than Larsa, but he remains stoic and stern throughout the game.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): Of the [Necessarily Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NecessarilyEvil) [Visionary Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VisionaryVillain) sort. Vayne's goals are ultimately to  (SPOILER) free the world and Mankind from the unseen manipulations of the godlike Occuria, eliminate the political corruption within Archadia, and unite the world under their banner as a new Dynast-King to usher in peace and prosperity.
[Armor-Piercing Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmorPiercingAttack): He has "Piercing" magick, which ignores Reflect.

tropeName: Bad Guys Do the Dirty Work
tropeNotes: [Bad Guys Do the Dirty Work](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadGuysDoTheDirtyWork): His dream of a united, peaceful Ivalice is not going to be obtained without a lot of war and bloodshed, and with his father sick, Archadia will soon be ruled by either Vayne, or Larsa; who is young, vulnerable, and idealistic. Knowing he wouldn't be able to handle the throne in his current state, Vayne works to put himself on it for the sake of Archadia's future.

[The Bad Guy Wins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBadGuyWins): Played with.  (SPOILER) Vayne's dream of a peaceful Ivalice united under Archadia and free of the Occuria never comes to fruition, but only the "united under Archadia" part — his actions have revealed the manipulations of the Occuria to Ashe and Larsa, Ashe has reclaimed her rightful throne in Dalmasca, and Larsa has taken over Archadia. With two compassionate world leaders on the stage, and both of them being on good terms with Al-Cid of Rozarria, Ivalice indeed has a peaceful future on the horizon.
[Bare-Fisted Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BareFistedMonk): Pummels your party using his bare hands and martial arts.

[Battle Theme Music](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleThemeMusic): The harsher sections of "The Archadian Empire" for his first phase, and (SPOILER) Discord (Imperial Version) as Vayne Novus .
    - (SPOILER) His final battle as The Undying uses "Struggle for Freedom", a fittingly grandiose theme using fragments from "Arcadian Empire", "Discord", "Flash of Steel" and "Life and Death", all gathered to create an intense, imposing final boss theme for a battle atop the Bahamut.
[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): A top contender to the title of most central and important antagonist, though there are others.
[Big Bad Duumvirate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadDuumvirate): With Venat, but Vayne is more active.

[Big Brother Instinct](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherInstinct): He does a lot to keep Larsa innocent and insulated from the dirty work required for an age of corruption and war. When the Senate moves to target Larsa as their [Puppet King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuppetKing),  (SPOILER) this is the event which finally pulls the trigger on Vayne killing his father so he can frame and dissolve the Senate, thus becoming the ultimate ruler of Archadia .
QUOTE **Vayne:** Observe well, Larsa. Watch and mark you the suffering of one who must rule, yet lacks the power.

[Cain and Abel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel): Averted with him and Larsa. Though they are very different and are opposed ideologically, they still love each other and would never harm the other.  (SPOILER) Ultimately, it's *Larsa* who turns on Vayne, at the end of the game when the party confronts of the two of them.  However, the backstory implies Vayne murdered his two older brothers on charges of treason, though the details are unclear.

[The Chessmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChessmaster): Though you don't see him on-screen as often as other villains, it is made clear Vayne isn't just [sitting around doing nothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrcusOnHisThrone) and is working on securing more power for himself through politics and manipulation rather than just force. Aside from cutscenes that show Vayne playing the political game, his will is expressed more through the Imperials the party comes against that are acting on his orders. The manga takes it even further with additional story details: as Ashe and Rassler were engaged, insurgents in Nabradia sought an alliance with Rozarria over Dalmasca and sabotaged the engagement; fearing that a civil war would break out and lead to a massive power shift, the Archadians conquered Nabradia to stabilize the region, and by that time Ashe and Rassler were married and Dalmasca was dragged into the war as their ally. It is implied Vayne was secretly backing the insurgents to use their plans as a pretense for Archadia's invasion, and by extrapolation to what happened during the main game, that would mean he (almost) single-handedly engineered a world war.

[The Conqueror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheConqueror): Vayne is an established conqueror of many of the nations in the Archadian Empire and just finishes conquering Dalmasca by the end of the prologue.
[Cultured Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturedBadass): He's very intelligent and well-spoken, and a political mastermind.

[Establishing Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment): In his very first scene, on pure charisma he rouses a rowdy and angry crowd from contemptful to hopeful with a speech that earns him near-universal applause. Not long after, he invites Migelo to a banquet and promises to get Migelo drunk enough to drop formalities and start calling him by his first name. [Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil) indeed.

[Evil Plan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilPlan): His goal is to unite Ivalice through any means necessary.  (SPOILER) In reality, his true goal is to unite Ivalice and to free humanity from the Occuria .

[The Evil Prince](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEvilPrince): While he has no actual title of Prince, he is functionally this trope since his father is [The Emperor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmperor). Within the backstory, he killed his two older brothers on orders from his father, and during the game he  (SPOILER) kills his father and frames the Senate for it. In the aftermath he crowns himself Emperor and dissolves the Senate, giving him absolute power over Archadia.
[Evil Virtues](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilVirtues): Ambition especially, but also love, honor, and determination.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Also a [Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil) to [Emperor Palpatine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/StarWars). Continuing with the *Star Wars* parallels, Vayne is a powerful figure in a massive empire who later takes it over by dissolving the Senate, and leads a masked figure to fight for him using [The Power of Hate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePowerOfHate). The key differences lie in motivation and morality: Palpatine, aka Darth Sidious, was a megalomaniac who wanted absolute power and control, and while Vayne seeks the same, his motivations are considerably more nuanced and, under a certain light, even somewhat honorable, if still extreme. That being said, it's not a coincidence that both have giant super-weapons with megalasers that can destroy entire civilizations in one shot.
[Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss): And a [Sequential Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequentialBoss) to boot.

[Flanderization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Flanderization): Not to the same extent as Vaan, but the manga dials up his evil moments and makes him considerably less sympathetic than in the game, giving him more [Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog) moments to show his cruel side.
[Flying Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlyingWeapon): His Sephira swords fly on their own accord to attack.
[Genius Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusBruiser): A tactical expert, cunning politician, and competent fighter in his own right.

[Glowing Eyes of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlowingEyesOfDoom): Vayne's eyes glow [gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupernaturalGoldEyes) with mist whenever he activates a special attack. As (SPOILER) the Undying , his eyes glow sickly green, gold or blue depending on the attack.
    - [Red Eyes, Take Warning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedEyesTakeWarning): As (SPOILER) Vayne Novus in cinematic attacks and while delivering a [Motive Rant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MotiveRant).
[Godhood Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodhoodSeeker): He intends to use his manufactured nethicite to declare himself the new Dynast-King and rule the world.

tropeName: I Did What I Had to Do
tropeNotes: [I Did What I Had to Do](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IDidWhatIHadToDo): Though he harbors regrets after, he barely hesitates to do what needs to be done for his vision for Ivalice to be realized.
[Impaled with Extreme Prejudice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpaledWithExtremePrejudice): At the end of the game, Vaan impales him through the chest with  (SPOILER) Gabranth 's sword.
[Intergenerational Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntergenerationalFriendship): With Cid, who's old enough to be his dad.

[Ironic Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IronicName): His [One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel) form is named "The Undying." Note he takes this form after  (SPOILER) he's already been mortally wounded by Vaan running him through with Gabranth's sword, and he knows he has minutes to live at best.

[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog): While actually referring to the subjects as dogs, no less.
    - (SPOILER) When Drace questions his innocence in Gramis's death and threatens him, Vayne orders Gabranth, her confidante, to execute her right then and there. He also refers to Gabranth as a dog and reveals he knows Gabranth was spying on him under Gramis's orders, and thus the execution is a test of loyalty. - In the manga, Vaan is caught and hauled before Vayne and Gabranth during the resistance attack on the palace. Vayne mocks Vaan as a powerless dog too weak and cowardly to do anything than kneel before him, then when Vaan mentions his brother died at Nalbina, Vayne replies since they were a family of dogs they wouldn't have had to pay for a funeral, and Vaan should be grateful for that. When Vayne's taunting finally pushes Vaan to throw a punch at him, Gabranth defends Vayne and Vayne orders him executed for trying to attack him. When Gabranth asks if they should show leniency since Vaan is obviously not with the rebels, Vayne keeps to his order and challenges Gabranth on his dedication to the law, bringing up Landis and Basch to remind him where he loyalties ought to lie.

[Kung-Fu Wizard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KungFuWizard): It's not fully clear which attacks of his are [Ki Manipulation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KiManipulation) and which are nethicite-powered magic, but either way he uses them in tandem with martial arts.
[Long-Haired Pretty Boy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LongHairedPrettyBoy): Has long black hair and is a pretty good-looking guy.

[Magic Pants](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicPants): As  (SPOILER) Vayne Novus and later The Undying , his clothing dissolves leaving only the armored portions, which encompass gauntlets, boots, the tails of his outfit, and his belt with a convenient flap of armor hanging over the groin.

tropeName: Names to Run Away from Really Fast
tropeNotes: [Names to Run Away from Really Fast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NamesToRunAwayFromReallyFast): "Vayne Carudas Solidor" does not sound like the name of a heroic figure, [Grey-and-Gray Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreyAndGrayMorality) notwithstanding.
[Nay-Theist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NayTheist): His goal is to  (SPOILER) overthrow the Occuria and free humanity from the control of the gods.

[Necessarily Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NecessarilyEvil): Even in his quest to become the new Dynast-King that will unite all of Ivalice,  (SPOILER) and shake off the Occuria's yoke , he is very much aware of the atrocities he commits, and the tragedies his and Cid's plotting have wrought. His remark "my hands are stained with blood, I see little reason to stay them now" alone shows he's aware of what he has done and will have to do in the future to see his goals to fruition.

[Ninja Pirate Zombie Robot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NinjaPirateZombieRobot):  (SPOILER) As the Undying, he's a humanoid [Cyborg](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Cyborg) dragon empowered by [Nethicite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AppliedPhlebotinum) that fights with a [BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS) [Blade Below the Shoulder](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BladeBelowTheShoulder) on one arm and a [BFG](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFG) [Arm Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmCannon) on the other .

[No Place for Me There](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoPlaceForMeThere):  (SPOILER) It's hinted that Vayne *knows* the peaceful Ivalice he's trying to create would not accept him, a vicious and scheming warlord, as their king, and his plan is to ultimately step down and hand things over to Larsa, who *can* be the virtuous and benevolent ruler that Ivalice deserves.

[One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel): It's Square-Enix, this is not a spoiler.  (SPOILER) Though he does play with convention by doing it *twice*, first by growing muscle-bound and superpowered by nethicite to become Vayne Novus, then by doing a [Fusion Dance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FusionDance) with Venat and grafting parts of his airship onto his body to become The Undying.
[Power Floats](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerFloats):  (SPOILER) In his second and third forms, he hovers above the ground.

[Rank Scales with Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RankScalesWithAsskicking): As one of the highest ranking members of the Empire, Vayne is much more powerful than them as befitting the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss).

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): To the people of Rabanastre during his time there. Though the Empire is still occupying the city and soldiers walk the streets, Vayne is not a cruel or oppressive consul, and does what he can to keep the peace between the Dalmascans and the Imperials.

[Sequential Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequentialBoss): Vayne isn't physically fought until the very end of the game, and the team has to go through three forms of him in a row when they do challenge him.
[Storm of Blades](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StormOfBlades): His swords fly around and attack you without him even touching them except during special attacks.

[Taking You with Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingYouWithMe): Come the very last fight, this is the point he's reached. He knows he's dying and his plans are over, but before that happens he's going to repay the favor.

[Übermensch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Ubermensch): Vayne does what he believes is the right thing to do, societal laws be damned.  (SPOILER) And justified, since so few others understand how the Occuria manipulate the world's stage from behind the curtains.

[The Unfettered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfettered): A more rule-abiding version, he nonetheless states (in a conversation with Emperor Gramis) that he's willing to do whatever he must, even if it means raising his sword and taking life *en masse*. Especially if he can prevent Larsa from having to do so instead.

[Unstoppable Rage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnstoppableRage): At the end of the game, he finally gets angry and goes berserk when he enters his [One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel) form, and definitely stops holding back.

[Upgrade Artifact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpgradeArtifact):  (SPOILER) Uses manufactured nethicite to transform into his second form, the hugely muscled Vayne Novus. Also a case of [Hulking Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HulkingOut).

[Utopia Justifies the Means](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UtopiaJustifiesTheMeans): His ultimate goal is a peaceful Ivalice united under a single monarch, a new Dynast-King like Raithwall. However, he's more focused on the "united" than the "peaceful" part, for now.

[Villainous Breakdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBreakdown):  (SPOILER) Possibly due to [With Great Power Comes Great Insanity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WithGreatPowerComesGreatInsanity), once he transforms into Vayne Novus and witnesses Gabranth's betrayal, his collected demeanor collapses into [Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam) outrage .

[Villainous BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBSOD):  (SPOILER) Shortly after the Vayne Novus fight when he is defeated and his attack on Gabranth is stopped by Larsa, he seems to finally question if his plans have been worth anything or if all his efforts were for naught. It doesn’t last long, as Venat notes he is fulfilling his goals.

[Villainous Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousFriendship): Contrary to the Judges and other officers, Vayne's interactions with Cid are quite friendly and casual. It's clear the two respect each other beyond just working together on schemes.

[Villain with Good Publicity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainWithGoodPublicity): He manages to turn public opinion of him around 180° with *one* speech. To the kingdom he's just overthrown and put under military occupation. Amazing.

[Visionary Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VisionaryVillain): He sees himself as a Dynast-King that will unite Ivalice under Archadia's banner and usher in a new era  (SPOILER) free from Occurian rule.

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): His ultimate goal is  (SPOILER) to create a united and peaceful Ivalice (like the Dynast-King of old), but under the control of Mankind instead of unseen gods. .

[Xanatos Speed Chess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/XanatosSpeedChess): Plays a mean game of it. He can't control what Ashe and her allies will do, nor the resistance or Rozarria, but he still manages to get what he wants out of it.

[Adorably Precocious Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdorablyPrecociousChild): A reconstruction, he takes on responsibility because he *is* competent enough to be a player on the world stage regardless of his age.

[The Baby of the Bunch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBabyOfTheBunch): At 12 years old, he is the youngest party member (the second youngest is Penelo, who is 16). Downplayed in that he is *extremely* savvy in social and political matters for a kid.

[Badass Adorable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassAdorable): As a guest party member, he can be fairly high level — *at age twelve* — and seems to be fully trained in some style of [Archadian fencing.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWield) It can be odd to see him engage a nine-foot-tall Werewolf with an expression of [Dissonant Serenity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DissonantSerenity).
[Break the Cutie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakTheCutie): By the end of the game, everyone this kid loves and cares for is dead. You see him break multiple times as a result.

[Broken Pedestal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenPedestal): Towards Vayne as soon as  (SPOILER) their father is assassinated , but it's [downplayed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownplayedTrope) in that he still holds love for Vayne as his brother, yet knows he must be stopped before another massacre happens by his hands.

[Cain and Abel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel): Averted, Larsa and Vayne clearly love each other dearly.  (SPOILER) Ultimately Larsa challenges his brother's authority when he feels he can no longer stay idle to his plans.

[Cheerful Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CheerfulChild): Part of his charisma, both in and out of the Empire, is his tendency to be optimistic and look towards the future with idealistic eyes befitting a child his age.  (SPOILER) Even after the game's story basically destroys everything he holds dear, he continues to be optimistic, if wiser to the ways of the world, maintaining his friendship with the party and the Rabanastre duo well into the future.

[Chekhov's Gun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGun): Remember the manufacted nethicite he gave to Penelo and later took back? He uses it to  (SPOILER) stop one of Vayne's attacks from killing Gabranth and Basch .

[A Child Shall Lead Them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AChildShallLeadThem): A classic example, Larsa is young and naive and champions doing the moral thing no matter what the politics may say. This is why so many respect him.  (SPOILER) At the end of the game, with Vayne dying during the battle above Rabanastre, Larsa becomes the Emperor of Archadia at age 12.
[Combat Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatMedic): You'll probably appreciate Larsa most for his healing skills, but he's a decent fighter too.

[Crutch Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrutchCharacter): It's worth putting off getting to Mt. Bur-Omisace and losing Larsa in the party, because he's an invaluable supporter. Besides the fact that Guest Party members are always a good thing just to have a fourth character, Larsa's infinite supply of Potions make a lot of the optional parts of the game much easier. He's also got the Telekinesis Technick, allowing him to attack flying enemies physically, while your party members will be relying on ranged weapons and magick. In the *Zodiac* versions he loses his infinite healing items (Guest characters now use items from the normal inventory), but he instead picks up Cura, Bubble, and status-healing spells, so he's still effective.

[Dual Wielding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWielding): Dual wields a [Royal Rapier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalRapier) called [Joyeuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PublicDomainArtifact) and a Swordbreaker.

[Dude Looks Like a Lady](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DudeLooksLikeALady): Larsa's name, hair, clothes, and voice fall just enough on the feminine side of androgynous that most players (in the West, at least) assume he's a woman when he's first encountered in the game. Trope does not apply in-universe, though; all the characters know he is male straight away. Meanwhile, many players only realize when the characters suddenly start referring to Larsa as "Vayne's brother" and go, "Wait, Larsa's a *guy?*"

[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): Twice, first as "Lamont", later under his own name.  (SPOILER) He later joins the party against Vayne for the first phase of his boss fight.
[Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD): Has a brief one when Al-Cid reveals that  (SPOILER) his father passed away .

[Hyperspace Arsenal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HyperspaceArsenal): The kid is famous for having an infinite supply of Hi-Potions and X-Potions, and he is not at all shy about using them. Subverted in the *International Zodiac Job System* re-release, where Guest party members use items from your inventory instead. This means that Larsa no longer has infinite items, but this is compensated by him getting very useful white magic—more powerful than you likely have at his parts of the game.
[Intergenerational Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntergenerationalFriendship): With Al-Cid. His relationship with most of the main party could count as well.
[Item Caddy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItemCaddy): Larsa has potions up the wazoo and you will appreciate them.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): "Cooperation (Imperial Version)", a more lighthearted variation of the Archadian Empire's theme, befitting its most benevolent member.

[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): In the *International Zodiac Job System*, he has Cura, Bubble, Water, and Balance, along with some status-healing spells, and knows the Shades of Black Technick that casts random Black Magic for free.
[Morality Pet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoralityPet): For his brother [Vayne](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad).
[Musical Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MusicalSpoiler): His first appearance in Bhujerba as Lamont is briefly punctuated by the Empire's [leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif).

[Odd Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OddFriendship): With Penelo. They still communicate regularly through letters and remain close friends after the first game has ended. He even revamps Penelo's entire airship kitchen when her cooking *finally* proves tasteful.
[Princely Young Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrincelyYoungMan): He provides the page picture. Much like Vayne, Larsa technically isn't royalty, but is a prince in manner nonetheless.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): His goal is to be this for Archadia, doing what is best for the country and all of Ivalice instead of pursuing personal ambitions.

[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): He's a definitive version, leaving Archadia to try and bring the war to an end peacefully by working with the other side.

[The Red Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRedMage): In the *International Zodiac Job System*, Larsa becomes one (though different from the Zodiac Job's version of the game). He loses his infinite supply of Hi-Potion, but is granted many powerful white spells before anyone else, and even some black spells (plus the *Shades of Black* technique), making him a jack of all trades. Combined with his quite high Magic power, high MP pool, his ability to wield a sword and his very high evasion, he is a force to be reckoned with, though he still lacks in the HP department.
[Sheltered Aristocrat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShelteredAristocrat): While he is certainly skilled in politics, especially for a twelve-year-old boy, he is still incredibly naive.

[The Sixth Ranger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSixthRanger): The second guest party member introduced in the story (after Vossler and before Reddas). He also holds the most fellowship with the members of the party, not to mention being the only Guest party member to join twice and yet stay a Guest, essentially making him their unofficial seventh party member.

[Superior Successor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperiorSuccessor): Actively attempted, but not initially by him.  (SPOILER) Vayne figured Larsa would be a better ruler than he, so his plan was to, after all was set and done, step down as Dynast King and give the title to Larsa .

[Trauma Conga Line](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TraumaCongaLine): The war between Archadia and Rozarria, as well as the conflict surrounding Dalmasca, basically destroys every single person Larsa has held dear to his heart.  (SPOILER) By his brother's own hands, the war worsens and troops from all sides of the conflict perish, their father and Emperor is assassinated, two Judge Magisters acting as his guard die in his name (indirectly in Drace's case), and Vayne then rubs salt in the wound by making Larsa watch the Sky Fortress Bahamut's firepower decimate the Resistance's ships. Him raising his sword against Vayne and being forced to put him down is, by that point, an act of mercy for them both.

[Wise Beyond Their Years](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WiseBeyondTheirYears): He's only twelve, but is very intelligent, mature, and well-spoken, and manages to play a few rounds of [Xanatos Speed Chess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/XanatosSpeedChess) against his older brother. He seems to be quite effective at sweet-talking the ladies as well.

[Youngest Child Wins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungestChildWins): Towards Vayne, and his other two older brothers, who Vayne himself assassinated several years before the first game took place. He is the one to succeed their father.
[A God Am I](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AGodAmI): Shows this at the top of the Pharos when he gets a power high and talks about displacing the Occuria.
[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): Just like Vayne and Venat, there's a good and noble man behind the villainy.
[Badass Bookworm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBookworm): He's the head scientist of Archadia, but he still leaps into the fray with your party without hesitation, and can hold his own too.
[BFG](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFG): His rifle is longer than a greatsword, and his gatling gun is nearly as large as Cid himself. He somehow wields them with just his hands.
[Bling-Bling-BANG!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlingBlingBang): Cid's guns are all gold-colored with glowing blue details.
[Chainsaw-Grip BFG](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChainsawGripBFG): How he wields his gatling gun.
[Character Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterCatchphrase): "The reins of history, back in the hands of man." It explains his basic motivation in ten words.

tropeName: Did You Just Flip Off Cthulhu?
tropeNotes:
[Did You Just Flip Off Cthulhu?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidYouJustFlipOffCthulhu): His goal boils down to this.  (SPOILER) The Occuria consider nethicite their power to gift to man as they choose, and Cid's started mass-producing it so humanity can follow its own path instead of the Occuria controlling everything . Near the end of the game he provides this quote
QUOTE "To Hell with  (SPOILER) the Occuria and their stones !"
[Dual Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualBoss): With  (SPOILER)  Famfrit, who he summons partway through the party's second battle against him .
[Energy Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnergyWeapon): His cinematic attacks fire various laser blasts.
[Evil Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGenius):  (SPOILER)  Not truly evil, but he counts in the traditional sense as the mastermind of the villain faction.
[First-Name Basis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FirstNameBasis): Everyone refers to him by his nickname with title.

[For Science!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForScience): His entire motivation is to make discoveries for the sake of making them. However, he has a bit more justification than most, since  (SPOILER) the further he plumbs the depths of knowledge, the more he frees humanity from the Occuria that don't want humanity knowing the secrets to nethicite.
[Gadgeteer Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GadgeteerGenius): He's a gunslinger, a researcher into [Magitek](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Magitek), and builds robots to aid him in battle.
[Gatling Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GatlingGood): One of his special weapons wielded in his cinematic attacks.
[The Gunslinger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGunslinger): Wields assorted firearms in battle.
[Guns Akimbo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GunsAkimbo): Though when he fires them both they will still only do one strike.
[Intergenerational Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntergenerationalFriendship): With Vayne, respecting him and treating him as an equal beyond mutual plotting.
[Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam): Cid seems unable to keep his hands still or his voice low for very long.

[Mad Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist): He seems to fill the criteria, being a hammy kook who talks to himself at length and is the mastermind behind the technological innovations that Arcadia is using to conquer the world. However, Cid is actually a subversion. He's perfectly sane and knows exactly what he's doing. This is lampshaded by Balthier, who considered Cid to be the trope but after plot revelations admits "he wasn't mad at all" — Cid is just busy talking to someone other people can't see, likes being overly theatrical, and is obsessed with a particularly fascinating and important field of study. Though he does end up playing the trope straight by the end as he admits his plans and desires of godhood.
[Morally Ambiguous Doctorate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MorallyAmbiguousDoctorate): He's a doctor and he's a villain and he definitely fits the "morally ambiguous" part.

[Motor Mouth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MotorMouth): Slips into this before the second battle with him as he gets more and more excited (and [hammy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam)), with his cinematic attacks during the battle being less a sentence and more a single word. For example, his shout during his Gatling Gun attack: "Youwillseenopityfromme!"

[Multi-Ranged Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiRangedMaster): Normally uses a pair of [Hand Cannons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandCannon) but also has a gatling gun, and two different laser cannons in his [Hyperspace Arsenal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HyperspaceArsenal).

[Nay-Theist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NayTheist):  (SPOILER) He manufactures nethicite in direct defiance of the Occuria (and at Venat's urging). He was the one who spurred Vayne to invade the small countries south of Archadia to get at their deifacted nethicite. 
QUOTE ["The reins of history back in the hands of man."](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcWords)
[No Indoor Voice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoIndoorVoice): Even when he's comparatively calm, Cid tends to be a bit loud. When he busts out the ham, best take off your headphones.

[Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy): Come the late game he's come to realize that the huge amounts of power stored in deifacted Nethicite is too great to be worth the risk of trying to control, since they have a habit of detonating like nuclear warheads if used improperly.

["The Reason You Suck" Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReasonYouSuckSpeech): Cid delivers a rather scathing one to Gabranth once he attacks Ashe, both for disobeying Vayne and betraying Larsa's trust in him. Realizing that Gabranth wanted revenge above all else, Cid relieves him of his duty to protect Larsa and tells him to leave the tower.
[Strong Family Resemblance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrongFamilyResemblance):  (SPOILER) He looks just like an older Balthier with glasses and facial hair.
[Summon Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonMagic): He calls  (SPOILER) the Esper Famfrit  to aid him in battle the second time he's fought.

[Talkative Loon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TalkativeLoon): Everywhere he goes, he's incessantly conversing with thin air about his work and plans.  (SPOILER) This is because his partner, the rogue Occuria Venat, is [Invisible to Normals](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvisibleToNormals).
[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn): The party presumes he is this trope to  (SPOILER) Venat. When Balthier accuses him of this, an amused Cid corrects they are mutual allies.

[Villainous Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousFriendship): With Vayne and Venat. Cid respects Vayne and talks to him as a friend, and his work with Venat is truly one of equal partners pursuing a goal together.  (SPOILER) As Cid dies, he tells Venat he's enjoyed their work the last few years, and Venat replies the pleasure was its.
[Wave-Motion Gun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WaveMotionGun): His laser blasts in cinematic attacks are *huge*.

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist):  (SPOILER)  He really wanted to free humanity from the yoke of the Occuria... but then went and tried to take on such power himself.

tropeName: With Great Power Comes Great Insanity
tropeNotes: [With Great Power Comes Great Insanity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WithGreatPowerComesGreatInsanity):  (SPOILER) He didn't leap over this all the way, thankfully, but the power *did* have negative effects on his psyche.
[The Emperor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmperor): His current title and station as the ruler of Archadia and leader of the enemy forces.
[Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain): As the ruler of Archadia he's the real villain behind their plays for power, but does nothing personally to be an antagonist.
[High Collar of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HighCollarOfDoom): It's almost as tall as his head.
[Incurable Cough of Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IncurableCoughOfDeath): We don't know what exactly is wrong with him other than "he's sick", so we just see him cough now and then.

tropeName: My Death Is Just the Beginning
tropeNotes: [My Death Is Just the Beginning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyDeathIsJustTheBeginning): When he dies, the *true* gambits of Vayne and Cid begin to turn.
[Orcus on His Throne](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrcusOnHisThrone): He's very old and sickly and can't afford to do much of anything now.

[Sacrificial Lion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SacrificialLion):  (SPOILER) Vayne kills him and frames the Senate for it as pretense to become the sole authority in Archadia's government in a power play that really turns the game's plot on its head.
[Small Role, Big Impact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallRoleBigImpact): He's the reason Archadia is undergoing a power shift, and  (SPOILER) his death drastically changes the course of events.

[Staff of Authority](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StaffOfAuthority): Carries an impressive ceremonial staff to go with his position. Also fits with him clearly being very old and experienced in his position.
[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): Is very polite and well mannered towards others, yet it is a major antagonist acting against the party regularly.

[Ambiguous Gender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousGender): Is *specifically* voiced by a woman, yet the body is ... [confusing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoBiologicalSex), to say the least. The voice is also digitally modulated to mimic certain masculine vocal inflections too. Since the Occuria leader Gerun is in the same circumstance, it's tough to say whether the Occuria even *have* genders at all, or if 'female' is the standard definition for them (as opposed to male). Or they just all have female voices regardless of gender. Either way, it's never specified what gender Venat is.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): [Well Intentioned](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlidingScaleOfAntiVillains). It orchestrates a world war in the name of freeing humanity from the control of the gods.

[The Bad Guy Wins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBadGuyWins): Its goal was to stop the Occuria's manipulation of Ivalice and its peoples, something that the heroes have no problems with, and in the end it succeeds even though it and Vayne die at the heroes' hands in the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss) fight.
[Big Bad Duumvirate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadDuumvirate): With Vayne, but Venat is more of a [Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist).

[Blue-and-Orange Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueAndOrangeMorality): Like the rest of the Occuria, Venat's motivations are inscrutable and are simply interpreted and assessed by others with incomplete data, like Ashe and Balthier. It sides with Ivalice's mortal races and desires to free them from their brethren's thrall, giving Ivalice control over its own destiny and ending the cycle of war and death the Occuria has spun to keep "his'try's weave" straight. Yet to do so, it is willing to engage in atrocities on the scale of genocide and put an equally tyrannical (yet mortal) regime in charge in Gerun's stead. Moreover, it treats its allies in this quest as equals with kindness and honor, never withholds vital information from them or knowingly manipulates them, and rarely, if ever, takes overt hostile action against the heroes, only doing and permitting as much evil as is absolutely necessary to bring about the "greater good." By the end of the game it succeeds.
[Defector from Decadence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefectorFromDecadence): It didn't think it right that the Occuria manipulate humanity from afar and sought to change that.

tropeName: Did You Just Flip Off Cthulhu?
tropeNotes: [Did You Just Flip Off Cthulhu?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidYouJustFlipOffCthulhu): Essentially its entire plan. The Occuria use nethicite and its power to control the fate of Ivalice via controlling its rulers. Venat decides this is wrong, and the way to undo it is to teach humans how to make nethicite themselves and shake up the status quo.
[Early-Bird Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EarlyBirdCameo): That ink spot on the cover, alongside the Judge? It's it.
[Energy Beings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnergyBeings): Just like the rest of the Occuria, it is a flickering indeterminate mass of seemingly calcified magic shrouded in Mist with an invisible face.
[Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss): In a way; when Vayne is impaled by Vaan after the Novus fight, it fuses with him to become The Undying, who is the final opponent of the game.
[Fusion Dance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FusionDance): It merges with Vayne at the end of the game to become The Undying, the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss).
[The Heretic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeretic): Directly declared as such by the other Occuria, who cast it out and demand its execution for daring to let humanity govern its own affairs.

[The Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHypocrite): Ultimately resorts to the same tactics that it disagreed with the other Occuria using, including allowing rampant slaughter and genocide. While it forms bonds with a few mortals, its dialogue shows it sees most mortals as regretfully but utterly expendable to its plans for its greater good which unfortunately leads to vastly more harmful consequences.

[Invisible to Normals](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvisibleToNormals): Venat is invisible to and unheard by anyone it doesn't want to interact with. For example, Balthier had written his father Cid off for a madman for routinely talking to this "Venat" character that didn't actually exist outside his own mind. Venat revealing itself to the party in Draklor Laboratory quickly changes his mind.

[It Has Been an Honor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItHasBeenAnHonor): Its parting words to a dying Cid are to affirm that working with him for the past six years was as pleasant and enjoyable for them as it was for him.

[Laser-Guided Karma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaserGuidedKarma): Venat is undeniably benevolent as are its intentions, the party even shares its same goals, but Venat’s methods for freeing mortals from the Occuria are still extreme and harmed almost countless people. In the end Venat dies on its own terms with someone it trusts, though it is still a painful death brought upon by those who were put though great suffering because of its schemes. Ultimately Venat’s final fate is an interesting example of both good and bad karma hitting it.
[Man Behind the Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManBehindTheMan): Vayne and Cid are the main threats of the game, but only because Venat's aid enables them to be.

[Necessarily Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NecessarilyEvil): The only real way to shake off Occurian rule is to get rid of those they've put on the thrones of power around the world, steal their god-given tools of oppression, and permanently stop any attempts they might make to re-establish control. That unfortunately means an international war or two and some future apocalypses that could have wiped out mortals entirely if the heroes hadn’t done anything.

[Not-So-Imaginary Friend](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoImaginaryFriend): Part of the reason why Balthier abandoned the Empire was that he believed his father Dr. Cid had gone mad and invented Venat wholecloth out of that madness.
QUOTE **Balthier:** "So... He was talking to Venat all along. He wasn't mad at all, was he."

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): After Vayne is mortally wounded, Venat offers up its immortality so that he doesn't have to die alone. Similarly, its final farewell to Dr. Cid, saying it was a pleasure working with him.

[Puny Humans](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunyHumans): In sharp contrast to the rest of the Occuria, its motivation is that it does not believe that the Occuria (including itself) have the right to manipulate mortal affairs, and believes so precisely because the Occuria are above them. It is respectful of its hume allies and graciously compliments Dr. Cid on his resourcefulness when he tries to shrug off his accomplishments as due solely to its teachings. Although the fact it is fine with millions dying to further its schemes to free them, suggests there is some amount of 'expendable mortals' it is fine with.
QUOTE "Indeed what claim does [Gerun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TopGod) have on history's reins, seated on throne immortal, rent from time?"

[Purple Prose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PurpleProse): Everything it says is flowery and poetic. As a reference to William Shakespeare, its sentences are constructed in iambic pentameter, aside from the actual words used.
[Real After All](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RealAfterAll): The party all thought Doctor Cid was talking to himself. Then they find out Venat really does exist.

[Satanic Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SatanicArchetype): Venat was once a member of the Occuria, but left Giruvegan because it disagreed with the majority opinion (i.e. that humans need to be strictly guided). Because it cannot act on its own, it settles on influencing select humans to help fight its former brethren and their allies.

[Satan Is Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SatanIsGood): Played with. A rogue god rebelling against the status quo and aiding the villains... And it turns out it has quite benevolent and understandable reasons for it. Though despite its good intentions, its methods are extreme and cause a lot of trouble the heroes need to address.
[Spirit Advisor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpiritAdvisor): To Dr. Cid, then to Vayne after Cid's passing.

[Suicide by Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicideByCop): Having accomplished its goals long before the heroes even make the trip to confront Vayne on the *Bahamut*, it willingly forsakes its immortality to die alongside him at the party's hand rather than stick around and face whatever terrifying idea of "justice" the other Occuria might have in store for it should they get their hands on it somehow.

[Un-person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnPerson): To the Occuria, by and large. The statue meant to represent them is noticeably absent from the Occurian Throne high atop Giruvegan, and Gerun places great emphasis on eliminating Venat explicitly when giving Ashe the Treaty Blade.

[Villainous Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousFriendship): With Cid and Vayne. There is no manipulation on Venat's part, the two are actively aware of what they're doing with it and work towards the goal as their equals. Venat speaks and treats it like friends, not pawns or minions.
[Voice of the Legion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VoiceOfTheLegion): Has a distorted voice similar to the other Occuria.
[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): It orchestrates a lot of war and destruction, but to its own ideals of a good end.
