[You Are Not Alone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreNotAlone): Venat forsakes its immortality so that Vayne does not have to die alone, nor face Occurian judgment.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): Aside from Judge Bergan, who's an [Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy) brute, all the Judges are [Noble Demons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleDemon) with their own sense of nobility and honor, and some do question the direction the rulers of Archadia are taking the country. In fitting with the [Grey-and-Gray Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreyAndGrayMorality) of the game, it's just that they're on the other side of the war from the playable party, not that any of them are really "evil" (again, except for Bergan).
[Badass Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCape): Standard attire for them is a long black cape with the sigil of the Empire in red.

[Double Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoubleWeapon): Each judge has one, which is actually a [Bifurcated Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BifurcatedWeapon) that splits apart for them to [Dual Wield](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWield).
[Evil Old Folks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilOldFolks): With the exception of Gabranth, they all appear to be much older than the party or Gabranth.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): [Cool Helmet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolHelmet)? Check. [Judge, Jury, and Executioner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JudgeJuryAndExecutioner) with "Judge" as their title? Check. Lawful to the extreme? Check. Give these guys Lawgiver pistols and they wouldn't be all that out of place in [Megacity One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/ComicBook/JudgeDredd).
[Four-Star Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourStarBadass): They're the commanders of Archadia's militia and they kick a lot of ass.
[Judge, Jury, and Executioner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JudgeJuryAndExecutioner): Balthier sums them as "more executioners than judges."

[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): In the [Updated Re-release](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpdatedRerelease), you fight all of them as a team as the last seed of Trial Mode.
    - [Mirror Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MirrorBoss): Unlike most of the high level enemies you fight they fight using the same sort of tactics and abilities that the player does, even down to having the advantage of numbers. - [Artificial Brilliance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtificialBrilliance): Their gambit setups will counter most of the player's go to tried and trusted strategies to make things even more awkward.
[Praetorian Guard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PraetorianGuard): In addition to being the supreme commanders of the military, they serve as bodyguards to the Archadian Imperial family.

tropeName: Red and Black and Evil All Over
tropeNotes: [Red and Black and Evil All Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedAndBlackAndEvilAllOver): Their black cape with the Empire's symbol in red.

[Standard Evil Organization Squad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StandardEvilOrganizationSquad): Each Judge has a distinct weapon and armor styling, and aside from being the enforcers of the Empire their individual goals and motives vary quite a bit.
[Tin Tyrant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TinTyrant): All of them wear custom suits of full plate armor.

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): In the game they mostly only use basic magic, if at all, and generally are not very impressive bosses, not counting the *International* rematch with all five of them. In the manga adaptation of the game, they're each upgraded to [One-Man Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneManArmy). Bergan and Drace march across a battlefield knocking troops aside with ease, and Ghis kills a Firemane with one hit. When a Judge takes the field in the manga, it's a sign to anyone not on their side to go [Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap).
[11th-Hour Ranger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EleventhHourRanger):  (SPOILER) Joins the party for the second-to-last fight of the game.
[Animal Motifs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalMotifs): A stray dog with no home and no honor, just looking for a master that will feed it. Invoked repeatedly by Vayne.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): He's a broken man who feels he has no honor or pride after discarding his loyalty to his homeland and his family to side with the Empire that destroyed them.
[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast): "Even a stray has pride!"
[Break the Haughty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakTheHaughty): Actually he's already broken; the events of the game simply serve to break what little is left.
[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): Of the villainous kind; his hatred of  (SPOILER) Basch  is all that keeps him going when he's lost everything else.

[The Dog Bites Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDogBitesBack): Come the end of the game, he's finally had enough with his treatment and does something about it.
QUOTE  (SPOILER) **Vayne:**  The hound strays... treason bears a price! 
**Gabranth:** One I gladly pay!

[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): He's the right-hand man of the Emperor who personally carries out missions. On a larger scale, he's [Co-Dragons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoDragons) with Zargabaath, who commands the main branch of the airship fleet.

[Evil Cannot Comprehend Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCannotComprehendGood):  (SPOILER)  "You confound me, brother! You failed Landis, you failed Dalmasca, all you were to protect. Yet you still hold on to your honor. How!?"

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): To Basch, as a disgraced [Failure Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailureKnight) who keeps fighting, but while Basch fights by holding to honor, Gabranth is motivated by hatred. He was also is an antithesis for Vaan and Ashe who at the game emotional apex chose to [Turn the Other Cheek](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TurnTheOtherCheek) on the man who destroyed their entire lives while he's spent his life letting his hatred destroy him from the inside-out.

[Evil Twin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilTwin): He's actually a Deconstruction of this trope, having initially had good reason to hate his brother. By the events of the game, however, he was serving the country that originally assimilated his homeland. This may originally have been justified to him by  (SPOILER) his and Basch's mother being Archadian , but by the game's events he's gradually falling ever further, whereas  (SPOILER)  Basch was able to put his life back together and fight on even when all his honor seemed lost . That neither side is entirely right or wrong keeps this trope from being played straight, much like the treatment given to so many other tropes in this game.

[Exact Words](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExactWords):  (SPOILER) After Vayne transforms into Vayne Novus, Vayne tells Gabranth to defend his brother, Larsa, as he will have "much need in the Hell to follow." Gabranth obeys the command to defend Lord Larsa... by turning his sword against Vayne and aiding the heroes instead.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Of Darth Vader. Heavy armor? Check. Relation to one of the main characters? Check. Serving as an emperor's right-hand man? Check. Although the cyborg part goes to  (SPOILER) Bergan .
[Failure Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailureKnight):  (SPOILER) For the Republic of Landis, his homeland that fell to the Empire.
[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember):  (SPOILER) When fighting Vayne Novus.
[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn):  (SPOILER) Basch convinces him that it isn't too late to invoke this, motivating him to do so and help the party stop Vayne.

[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog): The way he tries to goad Ashe into taking revenge, by rubbing in the fact that he murdered her father in cold blood. He also does this indirectly to Vaan, but it happens at the point he already knows taking revenge won't do anything for himself or Reks.

[Knight in Sour Armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightInSourArmor): Villianous version. He lost his homeland to the Empire he now serves and is deeply envious of Basch for continuing to be resolute despite having lost everything. Gabranth has honorable traits, but he's ultimately fighting for the hate he feels.

[The Power of Hate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePowerOfHate): This is what he has to motivate him now. Also deconstructed when we see just how hollow and broken he is for living such a life.
QUOTE "Long have I walked in hatred's company. As long as I can curse your name I shall not be defeated!"
[Recurring Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringBoss): Gabranth is fought twice, once atop the Pharos and then before confronting Vayne on the Sky Fortress Bahamut at the very end of the game.

[Redemption Equals Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionEqualsDeath):  (SPOILER) Raises his sword against Vayne to help his brother and his allies, but the battle takes the strength he had left and he succumbs to his wounds during their escape in the Strahl .

[Shadow Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShadowArchetype):  (SPOILER) He is what Basch would have been having the failure to hold onto his principles and if he had chosen to serve Archadia rather than fight against it. Also, whereas Basch accepts the past for what it was, Gabranth constantly tries to cut ties with it, emphasis on 'tries'.

[Sixth Ranger Traitor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SixthRangerTraitor): Played with in regards to the other Judge Magisters. Though he eventually turns on Archadia, by that time the Judges aside from him are as one.
[Sword Beam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SwordBeam): His signature skill Innocence has him slash the air to sent out waves of energy.
[Take Up My Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeUpMySword):  (SPOILER) When he passes his charge on to his brother.

[That Man Is Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThatManIsDead): Like so many characters, he's discarded his past and his true name.  (SPOILER) He's actually Basch's twin brother Noah. At the end of the game when Basch calls out to him as such, Gabranth mutters he's lost the right to use that name. He keeps trying to convince others he has cut all ties with the past, while in actuality he is still haunted by it.
[Tragic Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicVillain): The rest of the tropes here should make it quite obvious.

[Unknown Rival](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnknownRival): Is on both ends of the trope. He *despises* Basch and in every interaction with him mocks and goads him, while Basch remains calm and regards him with collected reassurance of himself. On the other end, Ashe and Vaan despise *him*, but they don't even meet until near the end of the game and Gabranth doesn't think much of their hate except to try and use it to manipulate Ashe.

[Villainous Breakdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBreakdown): Suffers this after it becomes clear that  (SPOILER) Basch was able to transcend his past and hardship while Gabranth is still empty and bitter. After Basch defeats him he finally lets go and performs a [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn) .

tropeName: What You Are in the Dark
tropeNotes: [What You Are in the Dark](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatYouAreInTheDark): Alone and able to express himself freely near the end of the game, Gabranth betrays Archadia and tries to goad Ashe into causing a war.  (SPOILER) Comes back to bite him when Cid steps from the shadows and calls him on his treachery.

[You Killed My Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouKilledMyFather):  (SPOILER) Ashe is not happy when Gabranth (almost gleefully) admits to killing her father and essentially ruining her life (of course, this was his intention with the confession).

[Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy): He slaughters  (SPOILER) an entire mountain of peaceful refugees  for no reason other than he can. Even after  (SPOILER) Larsa allowed Gabranth to take him to avoid such bloodshed.

[Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight): It's largely implied, but still demonstrated in-game. The manga adaptation shows this is his normal state, with him leading the assault on the Dalmascan troop at Nabudis and clearly enjoying himself immensely.
[The Brute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBrute): Of the Judge Magisters as a group, and of the Archadian military as a whole. [Presumably](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WithGreatPowerComesGreatInsanity).

[Deadly Upgrade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadlyUpgrade):  (SPOILER) He had manufacted nethicite set into his *bones*. After the battle, a bright light appears on his chest accompanied by loud snapping noises. Balthier opens up his armor. [His look of disgust](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReactionShot) and the snapping noises implies that the nethicite *exploded Bergan's chest*.
[Demonic Possession](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonicPossession): Possibly by  (SPOILER)  Venat, to precipitate the slaughter of the Kiltias and galvanize Ashe's retaliation .
[Evil Sounds Deep](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSoundsDeep): Bar none the most morally repugnant of all the Judges, and he just so happens to have the deepest voice of them all.
[Facepalm of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FacePalmOfDoom): To Drace... With a *steel* gauntlet. That had to be painful.

[General Ripper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeneralRipper): He firmly believes that a leader must be forceful, ruling with an iron fist and showing no mercy to enemies. This drives his loyalty to [Vayne](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfettered).

[Gory Discretion Shot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoryDiscretionShot): The camera angle when Balthier opens up Bergan's armor after his death does not show (nor does Balthier elaborate on) what the nethicite did to his body, but Balthier's openly disgusted reaction is enough to conclude that it is NOT pretty.

[Jumping Off the Slippery Slope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JumpingOffTheSlipperySlope): Bergan was, if not kind, at least a more *sane* man at some point before the events of the game. Even in his first appearance in-story, he's rather brusque but somewhat level-headed. In his subsequent scenes, his  (SPOILER)  taking manufacted nethicite into his body  causes him to first  (SPOILER)  brutally throw Drace across the room , followed by his  (SPOILER)  slaughtering people at Mt Bur-Omisace before the nethicite destroys his body, killing him .

[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog): A particularly brutal example. He slaughters  (SPOILER) the war refugees on Mt. Bur-Omisace as well as the worshippers watching over them . This earns the Empire no advantage and had no reason to be done; Bergan was just being a murderous bastard.
[Might Makes Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightMakesRight): Believes Vayne to be best suited to rule Ivalice by virtue of being the most powerful and ambitious.

[More Despicable Minion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreDespicableMinion): He is the [Token Evil Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenEvilTeammate) of the empire, and it shows. His [Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist) bosses- Prince Vayne, Doctor Cid, and  (SPOILER) Venat - want to conquer Ivalice so they can bring world peace and  (SPOILER) freedom from the divine will of the Occuria , while his fellow Judges are decent people. Bergan, however, merely loves power and supports his bosses since it gets him more, plus he admires their ruthlessness in achieving it. He then slaughters  (SPOILER) a mountain of peaceful refugees  for fun.

[Oddly Shaped Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OddlyShapedSword): Both his regular sword and his off-hand sword are... unusual. The main sword is curved and spiky all over, while the off-hand sword looks more like a tuning fork with some rods attached to it.
[Psycho Supporter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychoSupporter): To Vayne. He's his most loyal supporter but is clearly a bit nuts.
[Serrated Blade of Pain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SerratedBladeOfPain): His main "sword" is a jagged mess of spikes instead of a proper blade.
[Super-Strength](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperStrength): Justified, since he  (SPOILER) merged manufacted nethecite into his own body!

[Token Evil Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenEvilTeammate): He sticks out like a sore thumb among the [Anti Villainous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain) ranks of the Arcadian Empire. His bosses all want to bring peace, prosperity, and freedom to Ivalice (paradoxically, through conquest). The other Judges all have at least some sense of morals and decency, some more than others. Bergan, however, is a bloodthirsty psycho who fully supports the idea of Arcadia conquering the world and brutally stamping out anyone who defies them. Even before he ends up [Jumping Off the Slippery Slope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JumpingOffTheSlipperySlope), he's easily the most violent and cruel of the Judges and of the empire as a whole.

[Younger Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungerThanTheyLook): Perhaps the game's most extreme example - he's *33*, making him the youngest Judge Magister seen in-game and the same age as Drace, yet he looks a good twenty years older when we see him out of armor.

tropeName: With Great Power Comes Great Insanity
tropeNotes: [With Great Power Comes Great Insanity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WithGreatPowerComesGreatInsanity): He's one of the most powerful men in the Empire, but also insane and devoid of morality.
[Carry a Big Stick](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CarryABigStick): Her weapon is a large club.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Several times.
QUOTE  "You wear the mummer's motley well, Bergan."
[Face Death with Dignity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceDeathWithDignity): She simply asks her executioner make it quick.
[Go Out with a Smile](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoOutWithASmile): She does it, knowing that Gabranth will take care of Larsa in her stead.

[Honour Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonourBeforeReason):  (SPOILER)  She might have lived if she, like Zargabaath, had examined the situation with Vayne killing his father more rationally .
[Mama Bear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MamaBear): She's willing to commit treason if it means protecting Larsa.

[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): When fought in Trial Mode she focuses on casting [Status Buffs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusBuff) on herself and the other Judges and using the extremely powerful Shock spell.

[The Smurfette Principle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmurfettePrinciple): She is the only woman among the Judge Magisters and the only female character on the Arcadian side to be named in the script or have any significant plot importance.
[Sour Supporter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SourSupporter): Towards Vayne, not disguising her disgust with his methods.
[Bling of War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlingOfWar): While the other Judges wear imposing silver and black armor, Ghis is quite a bit more stylish with a uniform of red and gold with matching weapons.
[The Chessmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChessmaster): Tries, but ultimately isn't as good as the *bigger* and more well-informed Chessmasters.
[Combat Hand Fan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatHandFan): His offhand weapon is a bladed one.
[Cool Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolSword): A stylishly gold plated one.
[The Corrupter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCorrupter): In the manga, he's the one who convinces Vossler the resistance is futile and he should ally with the Empire.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): Seems to have shades of this in his first appearances — especially compared to [Bergan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight) — but it's really more that he prefers to not dirty his own hands if he can help it. When the party confronts him, he has no further issue with attempting to kill them, though it must be acknowledged that he doesn't appear to hold a grudge afterward. Say what you will about his ethics — or lack thereof — but don't mistake him for a simple-minded mass-murderer.

[Faux Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FauxAffablyEvil): He's definitely cultured and polite, rarely if ever losing his composure even when  (SPOILER)  Ashe's group is fighting against him to escape the Dreadnought Leviathan . He's also got an enormous ego and an inflated opinion of himself which comes from being a cunning social climber. For instance, take this quote — the "last encounter" he refers to was when he *launched a Flare spell at Ashe fully intending to kill her*.
QUOTE "Such a tremendous honor to again be graced with your presence, Majesty. You left us with such great dispatch upon our last encounter that I must confess... I had begun to worry that we may have given some cause for offense."

[Hoist by His Own Petard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HoistByHisOwnPetard): He decides to  (SPOILER) stick a piece of deifacted nethicite in his airship's machines to test how powerful it is. It's so powerful it blows up the fleet.

[I Gave My Word](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IGaveMyWord): A villainous example; Vaan hands him the Dusk Shard but asks he promise not to execute anyone. Ghis doesn't voice agreement, but does order they be imprisoned rather than have them killed, even though three of the party members hold no political value.
[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): He's polite, yes, but still a creep.

[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): He has an [Aero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway) spell which is very powerful at the time you fight him and appears to cast [Flare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonElemental) during a cutscene. In the Trial Mode battle he will pull out powerful debuffing magic with [Curse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Curse), [Status-Buff Dispel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusBuffDispel) your own buffs en-mass and packs the very powerful [Scourge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlagueMaster) spell.

[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap): When he realizes  (SPOILER)  exactly what's about to happen to the Leviathan  after  (SPOILER)  the deifacted nethicite goes in the ship's drive, and the readings go red.
[Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy): He recognizes the value in using Ashe as a political pawn to placate Dalmasca's citizens, rather than just having her killed.
[Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake): He's eternally confident and condescending.  (SPOILER) And his lack of control and foresight gets him blown up.

[The Starscream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStarscream):  (SPOILER) He makes a very revealing comment right before his death that implies he'll use the nethicite to put himself on the Archadian throne. However, as the nethicite minutes later blows up his entire fleet, he has no time to act upon it.

[Starter Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StarterVillain): The primary Imperial representative to oppose the party in the first act of the game,  (SPOILER) he dies before any of the other judges aside from Gabranth have been properly introduced . The manga adaptation effectively elevates him to [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad), on account the other villains are [Demoted to Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemotedToExtra) as a result of the manga being cut short.

[Too Dumb to Live](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooDumbToLive): Really, Ghis — you just *had* to  (SPOILER) test the *deifacted nethicite* while on an airship, not stopping to consider just how powerful it must be if King Raithwall used it to conquer the lands all those years ago? With no safety precautions, or even knowledge of how nethicite actually works? You were asking for trouble.

[The Unfettered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfettered): Self-admitted.
QUOTE  "Methods do not interest me. Only results."
[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn): Of Vayne and Cid, to see just how powerful deifacted nethicite could be.

[Villainous Breakdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBreakdown): He finally loses his cool when  (SPOILER) the deifacted nethicite proves too powerful to control and starts to overload his airship's engines.

[You Have Outlived Your Usefulness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness): Invokes it on Ashe; now that the Empire has the Dawn Shard, they don't need the actual Princess anymore to claim her title. The second time he captures her, though, he just has her imprisoned under Vaan's pleading.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): [Noble Antivillain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlidingScaleOfAntiVillains). Zargabaath never acts evil in any way, he's just on Archadia's side is all.
[Combat Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatMedic): Zargabaath's designation when fighting alongside his fellow judges in Trial Mode is to heal the others with items.

[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): He's the eldest of the Judges, and he's also commander of the *Alexander*, the flagship of Archadia's largest airship fleet. This also makes him [Co-Dragons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoDragons) with Gabranth, who is the Emperor's personal aide.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): Fitting given he's not all that evil to begin with. He'll engage the resistance fleet in a battle, but when  (SPOILER) the *Sky Fortress Bahamut* is destroyed and her wreck is about to fall on Rabanastre , Zargabaath calls up the enemy and asks for their aid in stopping it (or at least, for them to not interfere while he tries on his own).

[Healing Potion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HealingPotion): In the [Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss) battle with him and the judges in Trial Mode he heals his fellow judges with Elixers and will turn his healing items on you if you attempt to apply[Reverse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReviveKillsZombie) to your party members.

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice):  (SPOILER) Subverted at the last second. He intends to ram the falling *Sky Fortress Bahamut* with his airship to keep it from falling on Rabanastre, but Balthier is indignant that he and his efforts to repair the engines are being ignored and asks via radio for the Marquis to tell "that fool judge" to wait for him to finish his repairs.
[Minor Major Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MinorMajorCharacter): He has the smallest role of the Judge Magisters, yet plays a relatively major role in  (SPOILER) the final stages of the game .
[My Country, Right or Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyCountryRightOrWrong): He loyally serves the Empire even as he disagrees with what its leaders are doing.

[My Master, Right or Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyMasterRightOrWrong): Zargabaath will express unhappiness with Vayne's deeds and try to appeal to Vayne's better nature, but he follows Vayne's orders to the letter and expects the other Judges to do the same - he gets angry when Drace even begins to suggest that the Judges do something about Vayne. It isn't Vayne *personally* he's this loyal to though, but whoever the ruler of Archadia is.
[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): He and Drace join the other three Judge Magisters as the final bosses of Trial Mode.
[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): He attempts to talk Vayne out of  (SPOILER) killing Drace .
[The Quiet One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheQuietOne): Even when he does appear, he doesn't talk much.
[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Easily the sanest Judge Magister, and arguably more reasonable than both the Senate *and* the ruling family.
[Sole Survivor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoleSurvivor):  (SPOILER) He is the only one of the five Judge Magisters who makes it out of the first game alive.

[To Be Lawful or Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ToBeLawfulOrGood): For most of the game, Zargabaath decides on being lawful — either regretting what he's witnessing but not stepping in (like when Bergan  (SPOILER) went berserk at Mt Bur-Omisace ), or appealing to Vayne, being rejected, and going along with it (when Vayne orders Drace's execution).
[The Unfought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought): Along with Drace, until the [Updated Re-release](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpdatedRerelease).

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): Despite surviving the game, Zargabaath has no mention in the ending or the sequel. His fate is a complete mystery, though it most probable he returned to Archadia with Larsa and Basch and continued to serve with them. He was intended to have a role in the canceled *Fortress* spin-off that would have confirmed this.
[Batman Gambit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BatmanGambit):  (SPOILER) The Belito hunt  is a hoax he puts out in the hopes of drawing out whoever has been attacking clan members on hunts.
[Breakout Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakoutCharacter): Probably the most iconic thing to the Ivalice Alliance after Judges, which is why he came back for this game.
[Edible Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EdibleThemeNaming): Named after [this](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mont_Blanc_%28dessert%29).

[It's Personal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsPersonal): There's a few Elite Marks he puts up bills for himself, because of this trope. This includes the game's [Superboss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Superboss).

[Manipulative Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManipulativeBastard): As adorable as he looks, as patient and kind as he is towards Clan members, his ulterior motives essentially boil down to this. Whether the player sympathizes with him afterwards is another story.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): The names of the prominent members of Clan Centurio; Kjrn, Ma'kenroh, Emet and Monid where Clan Nutsy's founding clan members in *[Final Fantasy Tactics Advance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTacticsAdvance)*. Unfortunately in the English version of *Tactics Advance* these names are randomized so the reference is mostly [Lost in Translation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LostInTranslation).
[Ridiculously Cute Critter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RidiculouslyCuteCritter): He's a moogle — being adorable is part of the package.

[Revenge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Revenge): His beloved master was slain  (SPOILER) by the great beast Yiazmat , and all the master's disciples were scattered to the winds. He created Clan Centurio in order to find (or train)  (SPOILER) the warrior(s) who would be able to match and slay Yiazmat, and thus avenge his master by proxy.
[Verbal Tic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VerbalTic) Since he's a moogle, he automatically uses "kupo".

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): Hurdy gets an appearance makeover and becomes a main playable character in *Tactics A2* as a Bard. Sorbet actually becomes *the protagonist* of a little-known flash game called *Dive Hunt II: The Adventures of Sorbet*. Horne, meanwhile, is central to a quest or two in *A2* where it's revealed that he's something of an "item afficionado."

[Color-Coded Characters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorCodedCharacters): Montblanc is green, brown, and yellow. Sorbet is in yellow clothes with a yellow pompom, Horne is red, Nono wears green with an orange pompom, Hurdy is blue, and Gurdy wears a pink and tan dress with a pink pompom.

[Gadgeteer Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GadgeteerGenius): Nono, as Balthier's chief airship mechanic. By *Revenant Wings*, he more or less has a legendary status among moogles. Also, his outfit is a [Palette Swap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaletteSwap) of the Tinker/Gadgeteer job from the *Advance* games.
[Portal Network](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PortalNetwork): Sorbet, Horne, and Hurdy run a teleport network around Rabanastre until Hurdy becomes a bard instead.
[Promoted to Playable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PromotedToPlayable): Montblanc in *Tactics Advance* and *A2*, Hurdy in *A2*, and Sorbet for *Dive II Hunt: The Adventures of Sorbet*.
[The Rival](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRival): In *Revenant Wings*, Nono forms a rivalry with Cu Sith, Vaan's mechanic and Master Artificer.

[Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThemeNaming): Montblanc and Sorbet (both desserts) have [Edible Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EdibleThemeNaming) going on while Hurdy and Gurdy (the youngest, and twins) have [Musical Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MusicalThemeNaming), named after an instrument.

[Satellite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SatelliteCharacter): In *XII* they're all this to Montblanc, with the exception of Nono. Other games in the series flesh them out a bit more, especially Hurdy.
[Sibling Team](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SiblingTeam): Though they went their separate ways after their master died. For the last hunt against Yiazmat, Montblanc brings them all back together.

[The Smurfette Principle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmurfettePrinciple): One of the [Ultimanias](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual) refers to them as the "Moogle Brothers" but Gurdy is the only sister.
[Team Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeamMom): In *A2*, when she appears in a side quest, Hurdy mentions that Gurdy acts more like a mom than a sister.
[Papa Wolf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PapaWolf): He is protective of the orphans under his care, and tries his best to keep them out of trouble.

[Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute): He has been helping to look after Vaan, Penelo, and the other orphans since they were young. Vaan is starting to feel like he is outgrowing Migelo's care by the beginning of the story, becoming more independent, but Penelo cares for Migelo in turn.

[Professional Butt-Kisser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProfessionalButtKisser): When the empire takes over Rabanastre, Migelo is charged with overseeing the catering for Vayne's fete. As such, he is nothing but polite and respectful to their conqueror Vayne, something which makes Vaan angry and bitter, causing him to view Migelo this way. Migelo, however, is just a humble man trying to do his job, knowing full well the power Vayne has over him.
[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero): He lays it on Balthier, whom he blames for Penelo being kidnapped by Ba'Gamnan.
[Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy): All of them, as their combined bestiary entry states.

[Bad Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss): Ba'Gamnan is aggressive with everyone, even his sibling lackeys. During the time Ba'Gamnan is (unwillingly) on your side in the sequel, he is actually quite happy to help you beat up his siblings because they made no effort to rescue him and carried on business as usual.
[Bounty Hunter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BountyHunter): He's tracking Balthier to bring him to justice, but only for the money.
[Breath Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreathWeapon): In *Revenant Wings*, if you train Ba'Gamnan high enough, he can learn [Bad Breath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusEffects).

[Casting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingAShadow): Ba'Gamnan has the Souleater skill, the typical ability of the Dark Knight. *Revenant Wings* makes it his class and gives him Dark Aura and Drain to go with Souleater.
[Chainsaw Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChainsawGood) [On A Stick](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/XOnAStick): Ba'Gamnan's weapon is a rotating saw blade on a pole.

[Color-Coded Characters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorCodedCharacters): Each of the four is colored differently. Ba'Gamnan is bright green, Gijuk is dark green, Bwagi is grey-blue, and Rinok is lavender.

[Demoted to Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemotedToExtra): Ba'Gamnan appears shortly into the beginning with an established desire to get Balthier, and soon after kidnaps Penelo to lure Balthier in. In the following battle, he's so tough it's actually recommended to *run* from him rather than fight (unless the player's been [Level Grinding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LevelGrinding)). Sounds like he'll be a major recurring antagonist, right? Well... no, actually. He basically disappears from the main plot altogether, reappearing as part of a Hunt, and that's it for his appearances in [Final Fantasy XII](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXII). He does become a recurring villain in [Revenant Wings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXIIRevenantWings). You even get the chance to play as him for a brief portion of the game.
[Devious Daggers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeviousDaggers): Bwagi and Rinok fight with daggers in *Revenant Wings*.

[Disney Villain Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisneyVillainDeath): He's last seen falling off a refinery tower into the depths of the Sandsea. [He gets better in Revenant Wings.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnexplainedRecovery)
[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Fitting with Balthier being an Expy of Han Solo, Ba'Gamnan is his Boba Fett, allying with the Empire to track him down.
[Fire, Ice, Lightning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FireIceLightning): Bwagi can cast spells in these three elements. Gijuk uses the three colored fangs for the same.
[Goldfish Poop Gang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoldfishPoopGang): He and his siblings in *Revenant Wings* serve as recurring bosses.
[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): In *Revenant Wings*, Ba'Gamnan is playable. [And hates every second of it.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeethClenchedTeamwork)
[The Gunslinger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGunslinger): Gijuk's weapon is a gun in cutscenes. He trades it in for a crossbow in the actual fights.

[Hopeless Boss Fight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopelessBossFight): Subverted. He and his flunkies appear as enemies after Penelo is rescued, but unless the party is overleveled they're near impossible to defeat, so it's generally better to run.

[I Have Your Wife](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveYourWife): He kidnaps Penelo in *XII* and Filo in *Revenant Wings*, both times to use as leverage against Vaan and Balthier. It fails both times due to them being rescued. He even attempted to kidnap Fran in *Revenant Wings*, though Vaan nipped those plans in the bud.
[Improbable Weapon User](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableWeaponUser): Ba'Gamnan uses a large circular spinning chainsaw type of weapon called the "Ba'Gangsaw."
[Lizard Folk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LizardFolk): As bangaa, they're lizard-men and women.
[Loves the Sound of Screaming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LovesTheSoundOfScreaming): Gijuk.
[Recurring Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringBoss): A few times in the first game but even more in the sequel, where they get more focus in general.
[Satellite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SatelliteCharacter): Ba'Gamnan's siblings mostly exist just to be his minions.
[Sibling Team](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SiblingTeam): All 4 of them are siblings.
[The Smurfette Principle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmurfettePrinciple): One of his minions is the only noteworthy female Bangaa of the entire story.

[Unusable Enemy Equipment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnusableEnemyEquipment): Subverted, most of their weapons are obtainable in-game: Rinok wields the Gungnir and the Javelin, while Gijuk has the Aldebran and the Bowgun. The exception is Ba'Gamnan's weapon, a sort of buzzsaw polearm.
[Violent Glaswegian](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ViolentGlaswegian): Ba'Gamnan and Gijuk both have vaguely Scottish-sounding accents.

tropeName: Break Her Heart to Save Her
tropeNotes: [Break Her Heart to Save Her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakHerHeartToSaveHer): After the party frees her and brings her back to Eruyt Village, Mjrn implores Fran to convince Jote to allow her to leave, as Fran once did. For her own safety, Fran herself tells Mjrn to stay, causing Mjrn to run off crying.

[Demonic Possession](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonicPossession): Thanks to the Archadian scientists exposing her to dangerous levels of Mist,  (SPOILER) it leaves her susceptible to Venat's possession, who controls her to free Tiamat. She is soon released after Tiamat is defeated, however .
[The Outside World](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheOutsideWorld): Mjrn longs to see the world outside Golmore Jungle, and believes the Viera have archaic beliefs for staying sequestered from it.

[Unstoppable Rage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnstoppableRage): Exposure to the nethicite induces her into a berserk rage, which gives her strength to escape from the Archadian scientists in the Henne Mines but causes problems for the party  (SPOILER) and renders her susceptible to Venat's possession .

[Ice Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IceQueen): Jote is always calm and collected, and a bit frosty to the outsiders who have come into her village — and with good reason, as their people typically avoid the outside world.

[Lying to Protect Your Feelings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LyingToProtectYourFeelings): Before leaving Eruyt Village again, Fran asks Jote if the Wood misses her for leaving it. Jote can only respond sadly that it does, but Fran sees through it at once but is grateful all the same for Jote's attempt to soften her pain.
QUOTE **Fran**: "A pleasant lie, that."

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Despite their hatred of Humes, Jote gives Fran and the others Lente's Tear for helping Mjrn and returning her home, enabling them to pass through Golmore Jungle to continue their journey.

[Sugar-and-Ice Personality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SugarAndIcePersonality): Despite appearing standoffish, she cares deeply for both of her sisters and is hurt by how they both wish to abandon the ways of their people by leaving the Wood. When Fran left the village, she had to uphold their laws to forbid her entry ever again.

[Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton): The Occuria are furious over Venat helping the Archadians make their own nethicite and want nothing but their complete and utter destruction, collateral damage be damned. Gerun doesn't take it well when Ashe says Venat is an Occuria too. This outrages the Occuria king so much that it loses its composure and its eyes flare with fury. The other Occuria manifest their physical forms, angered by Ashe's statement.
QUOTE **Gerun:** The nethicite is *ours* to give, to chosen bearer or to none. 
The heretic tresspassed, and set the rose of knowledge in Man's hand. 
With imitations they *profane... it is anathema to us!* 
We give you now the Stone and Task! Administer judgement: **DESTROY THEM ALL!!!**

[Blue-and-Orange Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueAndOrangeMorality): Essentially, they view their actions as promoting peace among mortals. Sometimes their actions can make things look beneficial, but if they see something as an obstacle to their vision of how the world should be, they will take any means to remove it, regardless of what it is.
[Energy Beings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnergyBeings): They are mysterious floating masses of mist with blank faces and glowing orange eyes.
[Enigmatic Empowering Entity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnigmaticEmpoweringEntity): Whatever they are, they grant their favor to those who they deem worthy of power.
[God Is Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodIsEvil): What Venat thinks, anyways. Not to say they aren't probably right, though, given how overbearing and temperamental Gerun is.

[Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain): Their control over history is what spurred Venat to turn, making them responsible for the whole plot. They also act as a collective [Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain) for the entire Ivalice Alliance, given how every other game set in Ivalice (except for *Tactics Advance*) follow this one chronologically.
[Invisible to Normals](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvisibleToNormals): Well, to anyone they don't want to talk to anyway.

[Jerkass Gods](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassGods): Beyond their manipulations, if they see something as an obstacle to how they think the world should be, they don't care if its an entire country, they will use any means to remove it.
[Manipulative Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManipulativeBastard): They manipulate Ashe's emotions via visions of Rasler to encourage her to fight Archadia.
[No Gender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoGender): None of the Occuria are clearly male or female.
[Our Ghosts Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurGhostsAreDifferent): It is they who conjure the ghosts of Rasler and Reks to manipulate Ashe and Vaan.
[Screw You, Elves!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewYouElves): Venat's opinion of them, feeling they have no right to manipulate mortals. Ashe has it by the end of the game.
[Top God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TopGod): Gerun is their leader.
[Voice of the Legion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VoiceOfTheLegion): Gerun's voice echoes.

[Achilles' Heel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AchillesHeel): Provided you're fighting an Esper with a clear elemental affinity, they'll be naturally weaker against that element's opposite. That being said, the Espers are dangerous opponents in part because they have ways to get around their own weaknesses, like raising [protective pailings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LuckilyMyShieldWillProtectMe). [Some can even change elemental weakness on the fly without warning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheComputerIsACheatingBastard).
    - As summons, they collectively have one in the form of "Breakart Pentagram", an enemy magick attack that deals triple damage against them specifically. This is slightly [downplayed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownplayedTrope) because only five enemies in the entire game know it note  the Elvorets, the Diabolos and Piscodaemon Marks, the Shadowseer Elite Mark and the Hell Wyrm boss , and even then a quick/lucky player can still get their Esper's [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak) off before it connects.

[Anti-Frustration Features](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiFrustrationFeatures): Esper gambits were impossible to change or interact with at all in the original game, and if you wanted to see their respective [Limit Breaks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak), you'd have to meet very specific requirements. All of this made summoning a very situational tactic at best, and utterly useless at worst despite the genuine power they have. From the *International Zodiac Job* version onwards, it's now possible to directly control the Esper you summon and decide what its next move will be - and while you can't outright change their gambits, you *can* turn them on or off as you please and focus on direct input instead, making them far more useful in boss battles should you acquire the right Esper.

[Arm Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmCannon):
    - Shemhazai has crossbows attached to her arms that she uses during her [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak). - Zeromus has an organic one on his right arm that he uses for his [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak).

[Artificial Stupidity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtificialStupidity): Most elemental Espers will resort to other attacks if their target absorbs their element (for example, Belias will do normal attacks if his target absorbs fire, rather than Painflare), but they will still unleash their elemental limit break if their summoning time is almost up or the enemy's HP is less than 30%, regardless if the target absorbs the element. Both gambits take precedence and, since you can't change them, you have no choice but to manually abort the summoning if it happens. Thankfully, later ports of the game mitigate this in some ways.

[Awesome, but Impractical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwesomeButImpractical): All of them are this in the original game. If you want to summon them in the first place, you have to give up your MP. The Espers basically act like glorified guest party members; you can neither control them nor change their gambits, but depend on you for healing (except for Zalera and Cúchulainn, who have self-healing gambits). Most of the time, players summon them to unleash their [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak), but because their gambits are unknown [outside of consulting a guide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuideDangIt), you will not know how to do it. Even if you *do* know, a few are rather impractical to perform (infamously, Ultima will only do her limit break if her and her summoner's HP are both critical). Finally, they *can* be KO'd, and if the summoner is KO'd, the Esper will go away as well.
[Checkpoint Starvation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CheckpointStarvation): There's no save crystal before facing Zodiark. Likewise, Chaos is in an area with no save crystals whatsoever.

tropeName: The Computer Is a Cheating Bastard
tropeNotes: [The Computer Is a Cheating Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheComputerIsACheatingBastard): In the original Japanase version only, Adrammelech and Hashmal could become temporarily invincible for a time by using Perfect Defense.

[Continuity Nod](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContinuityNod): To the Lucavi from *[Final Fantasy Tactics](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTactics)*. Being that the two games are in the same continuity, it's heavily implied, if not outright stated that the Espers and the Lucavi are one and the same.
[Defeat Means Playable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefeatMeansPlayable): You can recruit them by defeating them.

[Demonic Possession](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonicPossession): *[Final Fantasy Tactics A2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTacticsA2)* delved a bit further into the relation between Espers and the Lucavi, stating that while Espers could be summoned, this would only manifest a fraction of their power. Only through [Demonic Possession](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonicPossession) could they invoke their true power—the Lucavi.
[Double Unlock](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoubleUnlock): You have to defeat them and activate them on the license board.

[Elemental Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalPowers): Each Esper is associated with a specific element, though five of them are [Non-Elemental](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonElemental) in terms of game mechanics.

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): All of the Espers except for Ultima and Zodiark have a counterpart who remained loyal to their creators. You don't get to meet them in-game, though.
[Fallen Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FallenAngel): All of them, thematically. Ultima is a literal one, having an angelic design.

[Field Power Effect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FieldPowerEffect): Several of them have these when you fight them. They include disabling magic, disabling basic attacks, disabling items, draining health and draining magic. Ultima cycles through them as well as two others used by other bosses.

[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): Mateus, Cúchulainn, Zalera and Chaos, all summon minions to aid them. Subverted with Adrammelech and Zeromus. The enemies in their areas spawn whether the Espers are there or not, and do so continuously.

[From Nobody to Nightmare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FromNobodyToNightmare): While not exactly nobodies in Final Fantasy XII, these mostly optional summons - outside of five story ones - are relatively unimportant to the story, if not connected to the story at all.  (SPOILER) But if the Espers are indeed the Lucavi from *[Final Fantasy Tactics](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTactics)*, then they are responsible for one of the most bloody and horrifying wars to ever hit Ivalice.

[Gate Guardian](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GateGuardian): Most of them, in particular the story-related Espers, are protecting something of value to the Occuria that the party requires for their own goals.

[Gender Flip](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenderFlip):
    - Zig Zagged with Mateus. The Emperor from *[Final Fantasy II](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Videogame/FinalFantasyII)* is male, the Totema from *[Final Fantasy Tactics Advance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTacticsAdvance)* is female, this Mateus is a black male fish who uses a Shiva [Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy) as power source. - Famfrit is based on the female [Cloud of Darkness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIII), but is described as being male. Subverted as, according to [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod), the Cloud of Darkness is genderless.

[Guardian Entity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuardianEntity): Four of the five plotline Esper happen because the party is trying to reach something that one of them is guarding: Belias guards the Dawn Shard, Mateus guards the Sword of Kings, Shemhazai guards the way stone to the Occuria, and Hashmal is the last line of defense for the Sun-Cryst.

[Healing Hands](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HealingHands): In the original game, Mateus and Adrammelech will heal their summoner if their HP is less than half (the former uses Cura while the latter uses Curaga). The *Zodiac* versions expand this to include everyone, who will heal their summoner if they take so much as a scratch (the Lv. 1 Espers use Cura, Lv. 2 ones use Curaja, and Lv. 3 ones use Renew).
[Horned Humanoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HornedHumanoid): Chaos, Zalera's skull, Exodus's humanoid section and Belias all have horns. Hashmal has antlers.
[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak): They all have an ultimate attack they can use that instantly dismisses their summoning when used.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): Chaos, Mateus, Famfrit, Zeromus and Exodus are all references to the final bosses of the first five *Final Fantasies*. Famfrit's reference is through his title of the Darkening Cloud, which the Japanese version renders as "the Cloud of Darkness."

[Non-Elemental](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonElemental): Exodus, Cúchulainn, Shemhazai, Zalera and Zeromus are all this is terms of game mechanics. In *Revenant Wings*, Zalera is holy-aligned instead and in *Tactics A2*, he replaces Zodiark as the dark Esper. Zodiark becomes non-elemental in *[Revenant Wings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyxIIRevenantWings)* and *[Tactics A2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTacticsA2)*.
[Omnicidal Maniac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OmnicidalManiac): There *was* a good reason for imprisoning some of them, namely Exodus. Not surprising considering who he's based on.

[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): You only need to fight five of them in the main storyline, who are appropriately manageable. The rest are a different matter, all things considered...

[Our Monsters Are Weird](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurMonstersAreWeird): All Espers have rather abstract designs to further emphasize their divine origin, Mateus and Zeromus particularly stand out as "alien". Belias might also count for looking like two humanoids fused together, giving him two heads.
[Promoted to Playable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PromotedToPlayable): The *Zodiac* versions make all of the Espers controllable by the player, though their gambits are still fixed.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): Each Esper have one: "Belias, the Gigas", "Mateus, the Corrupt", "Adrammelech, the Wroth" etc.
[Retcon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Retcon): *Tactics A2* gives Zalera power over darkness instead of Zodiark and *Revenant Wings* makes him holy-aligned.

[Shout-Out Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOutThemeNaming): Some of them are named after final bosses from earlier games: Final Fantasy I (Chaos), II (Mateus), III (Famfrit) IV (Zeromus), and V (Exodus). Cúchulainn, Belias, Zalera, Adrammelech, Hashmal, Zodiark, and Ultima hail from *[Final Fantasy Tactics](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTactics)* (which is set in the same continuity as *XII*). Only Shemhazai has no clear counterpart in the previous games.
[The Starscream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStarscream): They are punished for rebelling against the gods. Zodiark is an exception; he's sealed due to being too powerful.

[Summon Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonMagic): Instant-ally variety, uncontrollable in the original versions while the opposite in the Zodiac versions. In *Tactics A2*, the trinkets used to summon them all use the single-attack variety.
[Status Effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusEffects): Most of them can inflict at least one during their battles, often as an additional effect of their unique level-4 elemental attacks.

[Token Evil Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenEvilTeammate): The Espers are generally forced to serve the player heroes because the heroes beat them in combat. Left to their own devices, the Espers are shown to be thoroughly vile.

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): The *Zodiac* versions buffed the Espers significantly, giving all of them the ability to heal their summoner, making them controllable (and thus allowing you to use their ultimate attacks whenever you feel like it), extending their summon time to four and a half minutes (triple the original time), giving them more abilities and far higher stats (especially HP) and giving them all the ability to break the damage limit if they are strong enough. They're so powerful that it's actually a viable strategy to use Ultima against the *[Hell Wyrm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss)* (provided you're fast enough to use Eschaton before its [Secret Art](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SecretArt) kills her).

[Total Party Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TotalPartyKill):
    - Zodiark's Darkja ability can inflict KO to each individual party member (a 50-percent chance, or 25-percent when wearing proper gear), with the potential to do this. This is in addition to inflicting Blind, which doesn't wear off after a character is KO'd. - Zalera's Prime Level Death can be this, on the unfortunate chance that all of your party members have levels which are prime numbers.
[Western Zodiac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WesternZodiac): Each esper is associated with one of the twelve signs, and Zodiark with the thirteenth, Ophiuchus.
[Animal Motifs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalMotifs): Befitting the Aries sign, Belias has huge ram horns and his legs end in large hooves. Ram horns also adorn the end of his staff.
[Boss Room](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossRoom): The Cloister of Flame, deep within the Tomb of Raithwall.
[Damage-Increasing Debuff](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamageIncreasingDebuff): His Firaja can inflict Oil, which triples any fire damage received.

[Gate Guardian](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GateGuardian): He swore himself to the defense of Raithwall's tomb, standing between would-be trespassers and the chamber that leads to the Dawn Shard. The party needs to defeat him to get to it.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak):
    - Firaja as a boss, a party-wide Fire move that can also cause the Oil status, leaving your party more vulnerable to Fire attacks. - Hellfire as a summon, opening a deep fissure that causes a massive wall of fire to erupt from the ground and engulf all enemies in the vicinity.
[Magic Staff](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicStaff): His weapon. Not only does it serve as an effective weapon, his human half can also channel fire magic through it.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): It derives from "Belial", a demon in Christianity and a name used in the Hebrew Bible to caracterize "something devoid of worth", translated to "worthless" or "yolkless" in some translations. "Belias" is also similar to the word "Bélier", which is the French translation of "Aries".

[Multi-Armed and Dangerous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiArmedAndDangerous): Has two pairs of arms, one belonging to the beast half, and the other to the human half. The former performs Belias' physical strikes with his weapon, the other casts the Fire magic Belias is known for.
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): The Esper of Fire. Attacks with Painflare, Hellfire, and Firaja.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): The Gigas, called as such due to his huge size and for being a mixture of both human and monstrous features.
[Revenge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Revenge): Belias rebelled out to get revenge on his creators for considering him defective and useless.

[Warm-Up Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarmUpBoss): Because Belias is the first of the Espers, his battle is comparatively easier than the others', with no special field conditions or gameplay limitations, just strong elemental magic right off the gate.
[Animal Motifs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalMotifs): Pisces is the Fish, so Mateus' true body looks like it ends on a large fish tail and his weapon is an ornate trident.
[Boss Room](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossRoom): The Hall of Worth in the Stilshrine of Miriam.
[Damage Over Time](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamageOverTime): His Blizzaja inflicts Sap, which deals a consistent ten damage per second.

[Dirty Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward): His lore states that he attached an unrelated ice goddess to himself in order to face the gods by using her powers, her body essentially a meat shield for him to hide behind.
[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): Surrounded by four Ice Azers during his boss fight, which are weaker variations of the Ice Elemental enemies.
[Gate Guardian](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GateGuardian): It stands between the party and the Sword of Kings, which Ashe needs to cut the Sun-Cryst and prove her royal lineage.
[An Ice Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnIcePerson): The Esper of Ice. Attacks with Blizzaja, Flash Freeze, and Frostwave.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak):
    - Blizzaja as a boss, a party-wide Ice-elemental attack that can inflict Sap. - Frostwave as a summon, with Mateus freezing an *entire ocean* and shattering both it and [the screen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CameraAbuse) to deal damage to all nearby enemies.
[Living Battery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LivingBattery): That blue woman isn't actually Mateus. She's an ice goddess he's using as a power source. Zalera's shamaness has a similar function.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): "Mateus" is the Portuguese form of "Matthew", meaning "gift of God".

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): Named after the main antagonist of *[Final Fantasy II](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyII)*, also known as just "The Emperor", himself a once-virtuous ruler driven to evil by selfish desires and banished to Hell.

[Our Mermaids Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurMermaidsAreDifferent): As part of the Pisces motif. See that blue woman? That's not him. He's the [fish thing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FishPeople) she's attached to.
[Prongs of Poseidon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProngsOfPoseidon): He's a fish-like being who uses a huge ornate trident as both a physical weapon and a catalyst for his ice magick.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): Was driven to evil by sheer avarice and desire for power, hence "The Corrupt".

[Shoot the Hostage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShootTheHostage): Mateus bound an ice goddess to himself hoping the gods he fought against wouldn't risk harming an unrelated deity to hurt him. *Both* of them were cast down to Hell as a result.
[The Beastmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBeastmaster): The bestiary says that Adrammelech led an army of monsters against his creators
[Boss Room](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossRoom): The Athroza Quicksands, the center chamber of the Zertinan Caverns where the Mist is thicker.
[Glowing Eyes of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlowingEyesOfDoom): Adrammelech has eyes that glow yellow in the sandstorm of the Zertinan Caverns.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak):
    - Thundaja as a boss, which deals massive party-wide lightning damage. - Judgment Bolt as a summon, a massive bolt of lightning summoned from the heavens that deals huge lightning damage to all surrounding enemies.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Comes from the Assyrian deity "Baal Adramelech", with "Baal" meaning "lord" and "melech" being "king".

[Mechanically Unusual Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MechanicallyUnusualFighter): The only Esper to be considered a "flying" enemy in his boss battle, meaning normal attacks won't reach it, requiring the player to use magic, poles, staves or long-ranged weaponry.

[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): He's the weakest of the optional Espers but no less of a challenge to the unprepared player, especially due to being in one of the game's [most dangerous early areas](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrutalBonusLevel).
[Our Dragons Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurDragonsAreDifferent): A dragon with some goat-like features such as hooves, tying to his representation of the sign of Capricorn.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): Known as "The Wroth" for being extremely angry and irate in his judgements, and for his temper that led to his challenging of the gods' rule.
[Shock and Awe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe): The Esper of Lightning. Attacks with Thundara, Thundaja, Flash Arc, and Judgment Bolt.
[Boss Room](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossRoom): Terminus No. 7, deep within the Barheim Passage.
[Casting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingAShadow): In *Tactics A2*, it deals dark damage and status effects when summoned, replacing Zodiark as the dark Scion.
[Death and the Maiden](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathAndTheMaiden): His motif: a skeletal being representing death with a woman at his side.
[Dem Bones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemBones): Zalera's figure is very skeletal in appearance, and it summons legions of Dead Bones to help it in battle.
[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): Summons hordes of Dead Bones enemies during its fight.
[The Grim Reaper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGrimReaper): Its previous role of guiding the souls of the dead and deciding their fates in the afterlife serves as a variation of this.

[Light 'em Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightEmUp): Despite being considered an undead, Zalera is also technically a holy-elemental Esper. He absorbs Holy and will use it to heal himself if you summon him, though he no longer does this in the *Zodiac* versions. *Revenant Wings* makes this official.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak):
    - Prime Lvl. Death as a boss, a *horrifying* attack where the shamaness' skull is hurled at the camera while it screams. It will cause instant KO on any party member whose level is a prime number. - Condemnation as a summon, an attack where the shamaness' scream and Zalera's control of dead souls creates a hurricane of darkness around nearby foes. It kills any enemy with HP under 9999 in the original, but deals random damage in the Zodiac versions.

[Mechanically Unusual Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MechanicallyUnusualFighter): The fight against Zalera is timed, and failing to defeat it under the time limit will kick the player back to the Terminus 7 Adjunct, forcing them to try again. What's more, Zalera's spells (except Kill) are all based off the party's individual levels and dividing them by the spell's number (Lvl. 3 Disable will only affect party members with level numbers that can be divided by 3, etc.), meaning a huge chunk of his attacks can be outright ignored at the right levels. Finally, Zalera will erect a pailing that makes it "brace against attacks", forcing the player to attack it through alternate means.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): While not named after a previous villain, Zalera's design in this game pays homage to [Sephiroth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVII), with a black wing in the place of its right arm and the shamaness attached to it resembling JENOVA. Zalera's host in *[Final Fantasy Tactics](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTactics)* was also an [Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy) of Sephiroth, which further explains the connection.
[Necromancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Necromancer): Zalera wields the element of Death and, aside from using Instant Death attacks, also summons undead enemies to aid it in battle.

[One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill): As the Esper of Death and befitting his appearance, Zalera has a special "Kill" ability both as an enemy and summon. It's a single-target variation of the Warp spell, but does not require MP since it is technically a Technick. The *Zodiac* versions give both the standard Warp and Death spells as part of his summon repertoire.
[One-Way Visor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWayVisor): The shamaness attached to Zalera's arm has one.

[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): Arguably one of the "rewards" for finding the Barheim Key and venturing all the way into the Passage, all of which are sidequests and not required to further the plot.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): An actual angel of death guiding the souls of the once-living to their fates, hence "Death Seraph".

[Revive Kills Zombie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReviveKillsZombie): It registers as an "undead" enemy like the Dead Bones around itself, so casting healing spells at Zalera will damage it as if it was being attacked, which is a wonderful way to get around his pailing.

[Shoot the Hostage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShootTheHostage): Zalera grafted a shamaness who once serviced the gods into his right arm, using her powers to make his control over the dead that much stronger. Much like with Mateus, the gods just punished the two uniformely.
[Significant Anagram](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SignificantAnagram): Zalera -> Azrael. The Angel of Death.
[Timed Mission](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimedMission): Zalera's boss fight. You are ejected from the battle and have to start over when the timer runs out.
[Arm Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmCannon): Her arms are crossbow-like cannons that fire spiritual energy.
[Boss Room](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossRoom): Giruvegan's Gate of Wind.
[Gate Guardian](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GateGuardian): She guards the Way Stone that leads directly to the Occuria's realm above Giruvegan.
[Guns Akimbo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GunsAkimbo): Shemhazai uses 2 soul "guns" at once that can fire rapidly. Said guns are actually her hands.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak): Lacks one as a boss, but she gains Soul Purge as a summon, an attack where she rides under the moonlight and fires massive concentrations of soul energy onto enemies. Damage is calculated the same way as the Dark Matter item.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Derived from "Samyaza", a fallen angel of apocryphal Jewish and Christian lore once considered one of the "watchers".

[Non-Elemental](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonElemental): "Soul" is by no means an element or even a spell in this game, so Shemhazai's attacks aren't listed under a particular elemental affinity. Soul is used here mostly to separate her from Zalera and Exodus.
[Original Generation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OriginalGeneration): Shemhazai is the only Esper that's not based on either a Lucavi from *Tactics* or a past *Final Fantasy* villain.

[Our Centaurs Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurCentaursAreDifferent): Shemhazai is a partly-mechanical centaur, but in contrast to the typical depiction is more like a humanoid horse with parts of a horse body extending from her head.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): Called "the Whisperer" for revealing the gods' weaknesses to Ultima behind their backs.
[Soul Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoulPower): The Esper of Soul, attacking with Soul Purge and Devour Soul.
[Beast Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeastMan): Has leonine features to go with the zodiac sign of Leo.
[Boss Room](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossRoom): Heaven's Challenge, a one-time arena at the Third Ascent of the Pharos.
[Cat Folk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatFolk): Hashmal is a humanoid lion in keeping with him corresponding to the [Western Zodiac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WesternZodiac) sign Leo.

[Dishing Out Dirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DishingOutDirt): Esper of Earth. When fought, he uses Quakeja and an ability called Roxxor, which tosses a boulder at the target. As a summon, he gains the limit break Gaia's Wrath.
[Gate Guardian](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GateGuardian): The last line of defense for the Sun-Cryst.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak):
    - Quakeja as a boss, an Earth-elemental move that deals party-wide damage with a chance of inflicting Petrify. - Gaia's Wrath as a summon, where Hashmal digs deep into the earth then [rises with great speed, opening the earth itself under all surrounding enemies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Shoryuken).
[Manly Facial Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManlyFacialHair): A white goatee that flutters along with his mane of hair, making him look like an imposing beast.
[Maximum HP Reduction](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MaximumHPReduction): During his boss fight, his attacks have a chance to inflict Disease.

[Order vs. Chaos](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrderVsChaos): Hashmal's motivation for rebelling was that he saw himself as a bringer of order and thought he would subjugate the Occuria to the same natural laws he upheld.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): The "Bringer of Order" supposed to maintain the natural law upheld by the Occuria before he tried to subjugate them to the same.
[Animal Motif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalMotif): Only tangentially related to scorpions in that he possesses a stinger tail hidden within his body and is associated heavily with poison.

[Beware My Stinger Tail](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareMyStingerTail): Has one that sprouts out of his back during his [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak), fitting with being based off the sign of Scorpio.
[Boss Room](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossRoom): The previously-inaccessible No. 1 Cloaca of the Garamsythe Waterway, the only spot in the place that is seething with Mist.

[Damage Over Time](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamageOverTime): During his boss fight, he causes a continuous HP drain that's proportional to each character's health, making the Bubble status an outright liability as it causes health to drop faster than it can be healed. He can also inflict Poison and Sap, whose damage stacks with the effect.
[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): Starts his battle with four Foobars helping him.

[Guide Dang It!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuideDangIt): Easily one of the most frustrating Espers to find, requiring the White Mousse and Orthros hunts to be finished and having the key to open the Waterway's sluice gates in a certain way.
[Life Drain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LifeDrain): Cúchulainn's unique ability is Malaise, which is basically a much more powerful Drain spell.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak): Lacks one as a boss but gains Blight as a summon, where it reveals its real tail and plunges it deep into the earth, pumping lethal amounts of poison to kill the enemy.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Cú Chulainn was a demigod and hero from Irish mythology. A peerless warrior and master of the spear, he was best known for his ability (or curse) to warp into a monstrous, deformed berserker who destroyed friend or foe in his path.
[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): Locked behind a puzzle involving the Waterway's sluice gates, only available after completing two specific hunts.
[Poisonous Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoisonousPerson): The Esper of Poison, using attacks like Bio, Malaise, and Toxify.

[Status Effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusEffects): Cúchulainn's specialty is to sabotage the party by repeatedly inflicting different status effects on them through varying means. You better hope you have the necessary items to counter each and every one of them.
[Animal Motifs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalMotifs): His hand cannon and his tail are both concealed in what look like crustracean pincers, referencing the Cancer sign's image of a crab.
[Boss Room](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossRoom): The Throne of Veiled Gods, an area deep within the Stilshrine of Miriam, only accessible with a special key item.
[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): His arena has a near-endless amount of Dark Lord skeletons that will respawn frequently.
[Gravity Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GravityMaster): The Esper of Gravity, with attacks like Graviga and Gravity Well.
[Interface Screw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InterfaceScrew): His battle locks the Magic commands off, forcing the player to rely on items and techinques for healing.

[Judge, Jury, and Executioner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JudgeJuryAndExecutioner): Was once charged with upholding the law and punishing the guilty, but the amount of punishments he dealt made him enjoy it so much that he chose to try and subjugate the Occuria to death as well.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak): Lacks one as a boss, but gains Big Bang as a summon, a swirling vortex of gravitational power that forms into a huge shot fired out of his pincer hand, which is also a cannon. Because of how Gravity works in the franchise, the Limit Break does fractional damage to all foes in range.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Matching his inspiration, Zemus, his name is a pun of the original Ahramic term and the word "zero", essentially making it translate to "no prayer".

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): His name is a reference to the final boss of *[Final Fantasy IV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIV)*, the reborn spirit of [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) Zemus turned into a being of sheer hatred and malice.

[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): He can be accessed really early on, right after the party defeats Judge Bergan in Mt. Bur-Omisace and talks to one of the Nu Mou priests, who will give the player the Stone of the Condemned to access Zeromus' chamber in the Stilshrine.
[Power Pincers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerPincers): One covering his gravity cannon, and a huge one that protects its tail.

[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): Grew so used to punishing the guilty under his jurisdiction that he took joy in doing so and chose to punish the gods, earning the title of "The Condemner".
[Boss Room](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossRoom): The Empyrean Seal, a lone floating platform high above the Mosphoran Highwaste.

[Colony Drop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColonyDrop): Exodus's Comet and [Meteor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak) invoke this, as does his pre-battle cutscene. He's the only one who can execute the Meteor technique in *XII*.
[Interface Screw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InterfaceScrew): Erects a special field during battle that prevents the party from using Items.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak): Meteor, the recurring technique from the series, manifesting here as a giant asteroid summoned by Exodus' scale that crashes down and deals random non-elemental damage to all enemies in the vicinity.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): A translation error caused a bit of the reference to be lost, but he's directly named after Exdeath in Japanese, the main villain of *[Final Fantasy V](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyV)* who is also a being made out of a tree that seeks to reduce all of existence to nothingness.

[Non-Elemental](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonElemental): Exodus has no official elemental alignment, but his "element" is defined as "Aether", referring to the Comet and Meteor techniques present in other games. He also uses Flare and Scathe during his boss fight.
